The Pure Yang Patriarch of the Lǚ Dòngbīn Alchemical Dao
Annotated by Fù Jīnquán of the [Qing] Dynasty

I. *The Yellow Crane Rhapsody*

Profound indeed! The supreme vehicle is that of non-action and non-striving.
The Reverted Elixir’s sevenfold return arises only when movement yields to stillness.

[Annotation: The Dao is divided into three vehicles: the initial, the intermediate, and the supreme. Upon reaching the supreme vehicle, there is nothing to be done. From the Three Passes, one reverses course—upon the thunderous departure from the womb, returning once more to the origin of the first year—where sound and scent dissolve entirely, and vastness merges with the Great Void. Should the true face of *qián*-Primordial ever emerge, the Buddhists call this the realization of true suchness, thereby revealing that the initial and intermediate vehicles necessarily involve action.
The Reverted Elixir is the elixir that was originally one’s own. *Reversion* signifies returning from without to within, from the other back to the self, a departure that reverts, a loss that is regained. Seven is the complete number of fire; yang’s movement reaches its extreme and turns to stillness, while yin’s stillness reaches its extreme and turns to movement. Movement and stillness propel one another, each serving as the root of the other. The art of elixir refinement lies in seeking the impulse of movement within the depths of stillness. As Master Shào said: “Between one movement and one stillness lies the utmost subtlety of heaven, earth, and humanity.”]

The superior virtue preserves form through the Dao, for it is the unbroken *qián*-Primordial.
The lesser virtue extends life through technique, for it is the *kǎn*-Abyssal already formed.

[Annotation: The *Dao De Jing* states: “Superior virtue does not act as virtue; lesser virtue does not lose virtue.” The immortal teachings say: “Form is preserved through the Dao; life is extended through technique.” One must first possess the technique to connect with life before attaining the Dao to preserve form. The unbroken *qián*-Primordial is the undefiled body of a virgin child. Should one encounter a sagely master, no foundational work of life-connecting is needed—one may proceed directly to the ten-month practice. Yet such an occurrence is rare across kalpas. Should one expend even a single drop of essence, the body becomes leaky.
For those in whom the *kǎn*-Abyssal is already formed, one must first undertake the hundred-day practice of refining essence into *qi*, followed by the ten-month gestation.]

Thus, the Dao of yin and yang is employed, relying on worldly methods for cultivation.
The method of transcending the world imitates the procreation of man and woman, yet it must awaken the celestial mechanism to discharge the celestial mechanism.

[Annotation: The *Book of Changes* states: “The alternation of yin and yang is called the Dao.” *The Rootless Tree* says: “Apart from the Dao of yin and yang, nothing is complete.” This Dao necessarily pairs yin and yang, uniting water and fire. People see those who enter mountains to dwell in stillness, abstaining from marriage and office, and assume this is the way of cultivation. Yet the Dao resides among humanity, not within mountains. The Buddha said: “I cultivated the Way in the five turbid evil worlds and attained the Great Dao.” One seeks to transcend the world through cultivation, yet the method of transcendence is sought within worldly methods. The so-called worldly methods are the everyday affairs of ruler and minister, father and son, husband and wife, elder and younger brothers, and friends. Human procreation gives birth to sons and daughters; the elixir-refiner emulates this. Ancestor Zhāng Sānfēng said: “Following the birth of people, one reverses to birth the elixir.” A single phrase surpasses countless thousands—no more talk of desiccated sitting in quiescent non-action.
The *celestial mechanism* is the celestial root. Only by awakening the celestial root can one penetrate and discharge this celestial mechanism.]

To cultivate both nature and life in tandem, one must rely on the dual application of method and wealth.

[Annotation: Without life, nature cannot stand; without nature, life cannot be complete. Initially, one cultivates life through nature; ultimately, one completes nature through life. From beginning to end, this is merely the full realization of the two characters *nature* and *life*—necessarily cultivated together, never singly. The Ancestor did not say: “Cultivating only nature without life is like adorning a dull chime with black gold; cultivating only life without nature is like a mirror reflecting a face without a precious glass.” He also said: “Cultivating only nature without life is the foremost illness in practice. Cultivating only the ancestral nature without the elixir, the yin spirit of ten thousand kalpas will hardly enter sagehood.” Xiāo Liǎozhēn said: “Cultivating both nature and life is the true transmission—profound, obscure, and mysterious.” People only understand solitary cultivation in stillness; they do not comprehend the wondrous principle of dual cultivation. Departing from yin and yang, turning away from creation, there can be no accomplishment. If one wishes to practice dual cultivation, one must rely on the mutual support of method and wealth. *Method and wealth* refers to resources within the method. *Dual application* means both are employed to their fullest. This is essential from the outset, hence the phrase *must rely*.]

First, unite like-minded companions as assistants;
Next, seek a great household to secure a favorable plan.

[Annotation: Ancestor Zhōnglí said: “Wealth is not difficult to obtain; a companion is hard to find.” The *Cantong Qi* states: “The two sevens gather, assisting the practitioner.” Yíng Chánzǐ said: “Aides of like mind cannot be lacking; three of one heart must carefully support one another.” Tiān Láizǐ said: “To refine the elixir, one must find friends—three of like mind guarding one another. Without companions of the same aspiration, the great medicine will hardly form, and mercury will escape.” The *Essentials of the Golden Elixir* states: “One must select three fellow disciples as aides, mutually dependent.” Xue Daoguang said: “Three of one mind must guard against peril.” The *Song of the Cauldron* says: “Three people of one heart must be employed.” Across thousands of scriptures and ten thousand classics, all speak of three people—never has there been one who practiced alone.
*Seeking a great household to secure a favorable plan* means that to pursue this endeavor, one must rely on a great household. The common saying goes: “The golden elixir emerges from the wealthy.” Immortal Shí Xìnglín instructed Xue Zǐxián: “Go to a bustling metropolis and rely on someone of influence.” The *Essentials* state: “One must depend on a powerful household for inner support and outer protection.” Zhāng Zǐyáng achieved success only after obtaining Mǎ Dūyùn; Xue Daoguang completed the elixir only after meeting Zhāng Huánwèi.
First unite like-minded companions, then seek the opportune moment—proceeding step by step, one cannot expect sudden success without years of effort.]

】 Yet those who aspire to the supreme Dao must secretly knock upon the Mysterious Pass.
*[Annotation: When worldly people seek this most authentic Dao, its principles are subtle, its methods secret—rarely heard or known. There exists a mechanism most profound and wondrous; one must secretly inquire of the master and inwardly seal it in the heart.]*

Choose an auspicious site and guard the secrecy of the work; prepare the alchemical chamber and ensure the vessels are properly matched.
*[Annotation: An "auspicious site" is a blessed place; "guarding secrecy" means reverently attending to the work with utmost discretion, never daring to reveal it. Ancestor Dānyáng said: "Select companions, select resources, seek a blessed site." Master Shàngyáng said: "With companions and resources, much external protection—why must one retreat to deep mountains to become immortal?" Only with such a site may one then establish the alchemical chamber, where all vessels and implements must be properly matched. "Properly matched" means harmoniously paired.]*

Setting the furnace and erecting the crucible symbolize inner and outer—two Qian and Kun, heaven and earth. Refining the self and laying the foundation fortify both the personal realm and the state.
*[Annotation: Method, resources, companions, and site—lacking any one, success is impossible. Only when all four are complete may one set the furnace and erect the crucible. The crucible emulates heaven and earth, hence the metaphors of the Qian furnace and Kun crucible, or inner and outer crucibles. *The True Principle of Heavenly Immortality* states: "The outer crucible refers to the form of the elixir field; the inner crucible refers to the qi within the elixir field." Qian and Kun are called "two," and these two are divided into inner and outer. The Ancestor said: "Two layers of heaven and earth, four phases of yin and yang." Once the crucible is prepared, one proceeds to refine the self and lay the foundation. Without refining the self, the foundation cannot be laid; if the foundation is not laid, refining the self is in vain. Ancient teachings say: "Cultivation has its stages; refining the self is boundless." *Essentials of the Golden Elixir* states: "Gathering the medicine is easy; refining the self is most difficult." One must ensure the spirit is harmonious, the mind ashen, and the will settled. *The True Principle of Heavenly Immortality* says: "If unity is achieved, the foundation is laid; if unity is not achieved, the foundation cannot be laid." The ancients often compared the state to the human body: the heart as ruler, qi as minister, essence as the people. When essence is whole and qi abundant, it is called "a prosperous state with contented people." *Awakening to Reality* says: "Only when the people are content and the state prosperous may one seek battle; after battle, one may behold the sage." "The people content and the state prosperous" means the foundation is laid. The body is divided into self and other—how could the crucible and furnace not be inner and outer?]*

At the critical juncture, face circumstances without attachment, relying on the courage of keen vigor. Generally, temper the furnace and forge the sword, drawing upon the softness and hardness of Metal and Water.
*[Annotation: At the outset of practice, the crucial moment lies in facing circumstances without attachment. Confronting them yet unstained, one truly transcends worldly passions and forgets self and other. When beginning, all thoughts are emptied, the mind wholly devoted—entirely dependent on this resolute, keen, and courageous qi, may success be possible. *Essentials of the Golden Elixir* states: "With courage, success comes easily; with indolence, it is hard to achieve." The pivot of refining the self with Jade Liquid, the essence of forging the sword with Metal and Water—these are the spiritual roots of heaven and earth, the skeletal framework of yin and yang. Only when tempered to radiant sharpness may one soar as a spirit and walk as a sage. At the time of the third and fifth phases, the divine peak is keen and bright, hardness and softness responding in rhythm. The Ancestor said: "A flying spirit-sword with two edges—yet the returned elixir falls at the peak’s summit." "Tempering the furnace" means applying fire gently.]*

In operation, in withdrawal and addition, when encountering peril, one must bathe;

When plucking the zither or tapping bamboo, upon encountering contention, it is fitting to embrace the feminine. *[Note: The celestial gate lies in the hand, the earthly axis moves with the heart—pivoting yin and yang, steering the transformations of creation, wielding the mechanism of heaven and earth’s opening and closing, practicing the method of sun and moon’s union. Withdrawing lead and adding mercury, the curtain’s light shines through; the lead cauldron glows gently as dragon and tiger meet at the Magpie Bridge. At this moment, great peril arises—one must withdraw the fire, halt the talismans, and perform the work of bathing. Bathing means washing the heart and retiring into concealment. *The True Transmission of the Golden Elixir* states: "Bamboo must be tapped, the zither must be plucked." *A Sprig of Flowers* says: "Amidst the blossoms, I tap bamboo and pluck the zither, my heart serene as water." *Essentials* says: "First tap bamboo to rouse the dead, then pluck the zither to harmonize the sound." *Awakening to Reality* says: "Tap bamboo to summon the tortoise to swallow purple mushrooms, pluck the zither to call the phoenix to drink the elixir pellet." Tapping bamboo empties the heart; plucking the zither fills the belly. The classic says: "Water flows downward and does not contend—this is truly embracing the feminine." Laozi says: "Never strive to be first, but always follow others." *Awakening to Reality* says: "I urge you: in battle, do not underestimate the enemy." And again: "Let them take the lead; I shall be the guest." This is the essence of non-contention. Facing Qian and Dui, reversing husband and wife—here lies the meaning of harmony and accord. After a hundred days, the work becomes spiritually responsive, bending and straightening as circumstances demand. After a year, the work matures, and pursuit and absorption become effortless. *[Note: *The Jade Emperor’s Heart Seal Scripture* says: "When the returning wind blends, a hundred days bring spiritual efficacy." *Essentials of the Golden Elixir* says: "After a hundred days of work, marvelously seizing the celestial cycle, one bends and straightens, responding to things with spiritual agility." A year is roughly stated—ten months plus Mao and You. Xue Daoguang says: "In the first year, bathing guards against peril; in ten months, regulation requires careful moderation." *The Song of Gathering Gold* says: "In ten months, diligently swallow the elixir." By this time, the embryo is formed and the fruit ripens—pursuit and absorption follow the heart. This is what is meant by "three hundred days of fire, ten months of gestation." The spirit leaves the body, coming and going at will, erasing the record of death and attaining the rank of immortality—only awaiting the refinement of the spirit to emerge from the shell. Then follows three years of nursing and nine years of wall-facing.]*]*

"One steals the generative qi within that destructive force to infuse one’s own yin essence within yang. *[Note: The Dao is the mechanism of theft. From the depths of yin, one steals the utmost yang—thus the *Classic of the Hidden Correspondence* says: 'This mechanism of theft—none in the world can see it, none can know it.' This Dao unites water and fire in one palace, employing life and death interchangeably. The generative qi is sought within this destructive qi. Master Shangyang said: 'There is a blade that kills, and a technique that revives.' The *Awakening to Reality* says: 'If one can turn this mechanism of life and death, disaster transforms into fortune in the turn of a palm.' It also says: 'If one understands the mechanism of killing and its reversals, one knows that harm conceals grace.' The Three Powers steal from one another, seizing the mechanism of Heaven and Earth to attain longevity and deathlessness. Now, what I possess is the yin essence within yang. As *Awakening to Reality* states: 'The yin essence within yang is not firm in substance; cultivating this single element only leads to delusion and weakness.' One must obtain the generative qi within that destructive force to infuse it. Thus it is said: 'If only the essence of Kan infuses the cavity of Li, pure Qian can then embrace the flying jade.' Stealing from that to infuse this—how clear this is, yet why do people not ponder it deeply?]*

The Jade Liquid and Golden Liquid perfect one’s nature and one’s life respectively; the two phases and four phases are half in Kan and half in Li. *[Note: The Jade Liquid perfects nature, the Golden Liquid perfects life. The *Essentials of the Golden Elixir* says: 'The Jade Liquid’s returning elixir is wondrously subtle, relying entirely on the Golden Liquid to refine mortal lead.' It also says: 'Through forging the sword and grafting, one attains eternal spring and longevity of ten thousand years.' It further states: 'The great Dao of the Golden Elixir lies wholly in the communion of spirit. The subtle mechanism of the Jade Liquid has no other wondrous technique.' The six phases of one hour: the first two phases gather the medicine, the latter four phases nurture it. As it is said: 'Two phases to gather the pearl, four phases to refine the spiritual work.' Half in Kan, half in Li—this does not mean dividing the six phases between Kan and Li. Rather, Li is empty while Kan is full; Li is yang within yin, Kan is yin within yang. Thus it is said: 'Take the solid center from the Kan position, infuse it to transform the yin within the Li palace.']*

At first, one brings nonbeing into being, and already the dragon resides in the tiger’s position; in the end, one flows Wu into Ji, and only then does one know the tiger meets the dragon’s palace. *[Note: The *Token for the Agreement of the Three* says: 'Being and nonbeing interpenetrate; above, the spirit-virtue resides.' Nonbeing is nature, being is life. Bringing nonbeing into being is the initial work of entry, cultivating life through nature. Nature is the Azure Dragon, life is the White Tiger. Exploring the tiger’s den, plucking the tiger’s whiskers, seeking the tiger’s marrow—thus the tiger’s den becomes the dragon’s abode. Ji is yang earth, Wu is yin earth; the two earths form the jade tablet. The *Crane Grove* says: 'Flowing Wu acts as the matchmaker to approach Ji; metal returns to nature, celebrating the bridegroom.' The White Tiger is metal within water; the Azure Dragon is wood within fire. Wood and fire share a palace, metal and water become companions. These two entities contain the Four Images; their union in the mysterious palace coalesces the elixir.']*

Lü Dongbin, the Pure Yang Patriarch of the Dao of the Elixir—*Five Chapters*"

To discern the maturity of medicinal substances, one must distinguish the clarity or turbidity of the water’s source.

[**Note:** The true work of gathering the medicine hinges on distinguishing maturity. *The Orthodox Principles of Heavenly Immortals* states: "If the true work is unclear, though one gathers, there is no medicine to gather. If the medicinal *qi* has not yet reached pure yang, though one knows to gather, the medicine will not be gathered. For if it is too tender, the *qi* is insufficient; if too old, the *qi* has already dispersed—neither can form the elixir. The so-called water’s source arises from the Heavenly One’s generation, prizing clarity and purity, not filth and turbidity, and this also depends on the stillness and stability of the mind. An ancient song says: *When intent is settled and spirit at ease, the water’s source is clear; when intent is scattered and spirit confused, the water’s source is turbid.* Discernment must be constant and meticulous, execution precise, allowing no trace of blindness or ignorance.]

Those who refine the self and await the moment must wait for yang to arise in the Red County; those who encounter urgency at the furnace must ensure *gui* stirs within the Divine Continent.

[**Note:** *The Spring at Miluo* says: "The sevenfold return of the elixir first requires refining the self and awaiting the moment. When the first yang stirs, that is the time. Awaiting the moment means waiting for its arrival. The Red County is like the Red Water. The Dark Pearl of Red Water may be obtained in due time. Thus, when facing the furnace and its conditions, one must await the true moment. Those who encounter urgency act immediately upon arrival, for the moment must not be lost. *Gui* stirring refers to the time of *gui*’s arising. *Awakening to Reality* says, *'When lead encounters *gui* arising, gather it swiftly.'* *The Song of Gathering Gold* states: *'Know when *gui* is born, recognize when *gui* appears—thirty-six hours, two and a half days.'* Yang arises in the Red County, *gui* stirs in the Divine Continent. How can one who seeks the furnace and sets the tripod remain ignorant of this?"]

When one observes the dragon in the field, one must fiercely refine and intensely forge; when one suddenly hears the tiger’s roar emerging from its den, one may invert and reverse the process.

[**Note:** The *Book of Changes* says: *"Seeing the dragon in the field is beneficial for meeting the great person."* This is the second yang line of *Qian*, the perfect time for withdrawal and addition, requiring fierce refining and intense forging. It is not like the first yang line, the hidden dragon, which is too tender, nor the third yang line, which has already formed a substance and is unfit for gathering. *Awakening to Reality* says: *"The White Tiger of Western Mountain rages wildly; the Azure Dragon of Eastern Sea cannot be withstood. Seize them with both hands and make them fight to the death, transforming into a lump of purple frost."* *The Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir* states: *"The dragon comes from the Eastern Sea; the tiger rises from Western Mountain. The two beasts battle fiercely, transforming into the marrow of heaven and earth."* Inverting yin and yang, reversing the workings of creation, blowing the *xun* wind, fanning the bellows, from the Great Mysterious Pass, flowing backward to the Heavenly Valley Cavern, golden essence pierces the crown, silver streams surge like the sky, wind stirs in the Mud Pill Palace; the Crimson Palace shines with moonlight, the Magpie Bridge emits auspicious fragrance, sweet dew descends, the hundred vessels return to the origin, the nine passes are thoroughly opened—this is what is meant by *"When the union of Qian and Kun ceases, a single point falls into the Yellow Court."*

The fire compels the metal to move and exit the Kun furnace, hence the name "seven returns"; the metal, refined by fire, returns to the Qian tripod, called the "nine refinements."

[**Note:** The metal is the medicine. *The Kinship of the Three* says: *"When metal returns to its nature, it may then be called the returned elixir."* *The Guide* states: *"Fire compels metal to move, inverting the natural order."* *The True Blind of Chanting the Dao* says: *"People know fire overcomes metal, but do not know metal truly loves fire. Before metal leaves the ore and departs the furnace, without fierce fire compelling it, it cannot ascend."* Thus it is said: the seven returns are cinnabar returning to its origin; the nine refinements are golden liquid returning to its source. Seven is the number of fire; nine is the number of metal. Exiting the Kun furnace, returning to the Qian tripod, one gives and one receives, forming the return and refinement. One is nature, one is emotion, and this is called extracting from Kan to fill Li, returning essence to replenish the brain, illuminating the Li cavity, restoring the robust body of Qian—all refer to this meaning.]

The "return" is the substance Qian lost and has now regained; the "refinement" is the true self that departed and has now returned.

[**Note:** The precelestial Qian and Kun transformed into the postcelestial Kan and Li, meaning the middle line of Qian was lost. Now, taking the solid center of the Kan position and using it to transform the yin within the Li palace, what Qian lost is now returned to Qian—I am Qian. From the beginning of the primordial chaos, what was lost has now returned to its original state. Is this not what departed and has now come back?]

Little do they know that following the natural order gives rise to humans and beings, while reversing it produces immortals and buddhas.

[**Note:** The phrase *"little do they know"* means it is easily understood. Laozi said: *"My Dao is very easy to know, very easy to practice; yet the world cannot know it, cannot practice it."* Heaven and earth share the same root with me; the myriad things share the same body with me. Humans are the most spiritually endowed of all beings and grow alongside them. Thus, humans and beings are collectively named. To know the principle of becoming immortals and buddhas is initially no different from the principle of giving rise to humans and beings—only the distinction between following and reversing matters. Following gives rise to the ordinary; reversing produces the sage—this is ancient teaching. Master Tuo Yang’s *Entering the Mirror of Fire* says: *"Following produces humans; reversing produces the elixir. Grasping this principle, one becomes an immortal."* *The Rootless Tree* states: *"Following makes one ordinary; reversing makes one an immortal—only a reversal in between."* *A Single Stroke* says: *"If you know the origin of your birth, you will understand that creation lies in your hands."* Zhang Ziyang said: *"When the five phases follow the natural order, the common Dao has birth and death; when the five phases reverse, the elixir tripod remains eternally numinous and enduring."* *The Complete Methods of the Numinous Treasure* says: *"When humans first receive the essence and blood of their ordinary parents, they are turbid and chaotic, without form."*]

When the essence and blood settle, in the first month a gestational sac forms; in the second, the embryo takes shape; in the third, the hun-soul arises; in the fourth, the po-soul is fixed; in the fifth, the five viscera divide; in the sixth, the six bowels open; in the seventh, the seven orifices become clear; in the eighth, the eight luminous scenes are complete; in the ninth, the limbs are fully formed; in the tenth, the qi is whole—then the fetus emerges and is born.

The Way of the Returned Elixir largely follows this pattern. At the moment one receives the wondrous qi of the numinous father and sagely mother, the nine must harmonize with the ten before the metallic qi begins to arrive. It too is turbid and chaotic, an empty vastness of numinous clarity—no color or depth to rely upon, no form or shadow to depend on. The primordial qi rests in tranquility; the five phases scatter and spread, filling the encompassing expanse, silently congealing and merging. Drifting and roaming in luminous cultivation, it returns to the origin and reverts to emptiness; gathering and condensing in dense support, it conceives and nurtures the true, gives rise to the five viscera, orders the five qi, unites the hundred spirits, and knits the fetal immortal—this is called the yang-spirit.

Though it distinguishes self from other, it is in no way the chamber arts of bedroom alchemy.

Should one cling to the solitary self, how could one grasp the Peng bird’s mechanism for soaring south?

Though the distinction between self and other is already clear—where one steals the life-qi from the other’s midst of slaying to refine the yin essence within one’s own yang—this is further expounded here. While self and other are distinct, the process is upright and luminous, far from base, murky, or obscure. Observe the world: what does not follow the principle of duality? Where there is heaven, there is earth; where there is sun, there is moon; where there is yin, there is yang; where there is male, there is female; where there is self, there is other. Then consider cold and heat, day and night, purity and turbidity, movement and stillness, hardness and softness, husband and wife, female and male—is there anything singular that lacks its counterpart? To deny this is to lose the principle.

The ancestral masters, in their compassion to deliver the world, feared that people might misconstrue this principle as the chamber arts of bedroom alchemy, the consumption of filth, or the tactics of "bedroom warfare"—these are the delusions of hell-bound fools who fail to comprehend the matter of self and other. Thus, they reiterate: though there is a distinction between self and other, it is not that sort of affair.

*Master Zhuang* says: "In the Northern Darkness there is a fish, and its name is Kun. The Kun’s greatness—no one knows how many thousand *li* it spans. It transforms into a bird, and its name is Peng. The Peng’s greatness—no one knows how many thousand *li* it spans. When this bird stirs, it will migrate to the Southern Darkness." The Kun and Peng are metaphors for the vastness of the Dao, transforming into a bird, transmuting qi to ascend. From north to south, from other to self. The self is *li*, the Vermilion Bird of the south, containing within it the Wood-fluid Azure Dragon; the other is *kan*, the Dark Warrior of the north, containing within it the Metal-essence White Tiger.

The ancestral masters, in their mercy, feared that people would rigidly fixate on heart and kidneys, groping within the confines of their own bodies, and thus fail to understand Master Zhuang’s meaning of "soaring south." *A Single Stroke* says: "They say destiny lies within this body of mine—who realizes that the solitary self possesses nothing? This wondrous art, this mechanism, fundamentally involves the distinction between self and other; it is not the affair of a solitary self."

Within *kan* resides a speck of black lead, called the primordial—without its kindred, it can never be obtained; within *li* dwell sevenfold vermilion cinnabar-mercuries, yet without the true seed, they vanish in an instant.

[Annotation: The *Cantong Qi* states: "The *kan*-male is the sun, the *li*-female the moon; the sun bestows virtue, the moon unfurls its light. The moon receives the sun’s transformation, its body unharmed and unwaning." The single speck of true yang within *kan* is the black lead, the essence of mysterious water, the primordial true qi. The single speck of water-mercury within *li* is cinnabar, the essence of grand yang, the primordial true fluid. The *Lingbao Bifa* says: "Heaven-one generates water, and within *kan* lies lead; Earth-two generates fire, and within *li* arises cinnabar." Embracing the essence of Heaven-one, it stands as the chief of the five essences—this is black lead. Lead gives birth to silver, lead is silver’s mother; receiving the qi of grand yang, it becomes the foremost among all stones—this is cinnabar. Within cinnabar is born mercury, mercury the child of cinnabar. Hard to obtain is the silver within lead, easy to lose is the mercury within cinnabar. The ancestral masters, in their compassion, pointed out that to seek this speck of black lead, one must search among its kindred. The *Cantong Qi* says: "Kindred easily yield to effort, without the seed skill avails not." Again: "Attaching to kindred accords with nature, things form readily through refinement." Again: "Kindred follow one another, affairs contrary yield no treasure." Again: "Yin and yang intermingle, seeking their kindred." Ancestor Sanfeng said: "All else apart from this kindred is madness." The *Jieyao* states: "Only with kindred is success easy; lacking the elixir’s wealth, it cannot be achieved." The *Wugenshu* says: "Kindred align, work proceeds well." Without kindred, solitary yin cannot generate, and the day of obtaining lead will never come.

The *li* trigram is yang without and yin within—this is the self. Its sevenfold seven apertures emit the fluids. Ancestor Zhongli said: "Within the human body, inside and out, all is yin. What is the yang essence, the true seed? It is the primordial true qi—black lead." Mercury’s nature is volatile and hard to restrain. The *Cantong Qi* says: "Ghosts hide, dragons conceal, none know where they abide." Yet when a speck of primordial true lead arrives, true mercury naturally abides, no longer flying away. Like a cat pouncing on a mouse, like a hare meeting a hawk, it becomes docile of its own accord.

Thus, one borrows Qian and Kun to establish the crucible and furnace, seeking the true qi contained within the Great One, relying on yin and yang as the means to pursue the mysterious pearl stored in the Water Palace.

[Annotation: Qian and Kun possess the names of crucible and furnace; the crucible and furnace bear the designations of medicinal substances. This Way borrows the false to cultivate the true, turning the false into the true. The *Bai Ju Zhang* says: "Others know not our Way—clearly, the false is made real." Borrowing Qian and Kun as metaphors, one forcibly names them crucible and furnace. The *Fuming Pian* says: "The crucible—originally, there is no crucible." It also says: "This medicine has no furnace, only a crucible; one crucible transforms into ten thousand crucibles." Borrowing Qian and Kun as the names for crucible and furnace, one employs the imagery of the *Yi* to clarify the principles of the elixir Way. Yet one must grasp the image and forget the words—one cannot cling to the text or be bound by the symbol.

The true qi of the primordial Great One cannot be sought without the crucible and furnace; the crucible and furnace cannot manifest their imagery without Qian and Kun. Without understanding yin and yang, there is no way to begin. Thus, yin and yang are truly the means for refining the elixir. The trap is for catching fish; the snare is for capturing hares—such is the method. The mysterious pearl is the elixir. This pearl lies concealed within the Great Abyss of the Northern Culmen. To seek it, one must thoroughly penetrate yin and yang and deeply comprehend the workings of creation. Like the trap for fish or the snare for hares, one may then grasp it, avoiding futility and failure.]

In fleeting moments, swift as a breath, the broken line of Qian is mended; in an instant’s transformation, the six hollows of Kun are restored. [Note: "Fleeting moments" and "instant’s transformation" denote the swiftness of the process. This speaks to the ease of returning the elixir. The *Xinyin Jing* states: "Preserve the void, guard the existent—accomplished in an instant." From the first union of yin and yang, the middle line of Qian enters Kun to become Kan; the middle line of Kun enters Qian to become Li. Now, drawing forth the single yin from Li to fill the single yang in Kan, Li is restored to Qian, and Qian’s flaw is no more. Having extracted the one line from Kan to mend Li into Qian’s three unbroken lines, Kun in turn withdraws the two broken lines from Li, returning to its six hollows. The *Guizhi* says: "From this, the robust form of Qian is transformed—hidden or soaring, all lies within the heart."]

At this point, the heart returns to the chamber of spirit, and one is ranked among the Heavenly Immortals; the elixir descends into the Yellow Court, and a thousand spirits bask in serenity. The August Emperor bestows praise, and heaven and earth stand in awe. [Note: "At this point" signifies the attainment of this stage. Here, qi gathers and spirit is whole, the heart settles and spirit congeals, the heart empties and spirit becomes numinous. *Zhuangzi* says: "Its heavenly guard is complete, its spirit without flaw." The *Yinfu Jing* states: "The spirit that does not act as spirit, breathless yet ever-breathing, is ranked among the heavenly offices as an Upper Perfected." Once the fire of the numinous root is kindled and the pearl from the sea’s depths is returned, a single elixir drops into the Yellow Court. At this time, qi coalesces and spirit solidifies, the hun rests and the po is stilled; the entire body harmonizes, and the hundred vessels brim with spring. The Heavenly Lord is at peace, and the myriad spirits obey his command. The August Emperor bestows praise, honoring his valor. Heaven and earth stand in awe, deeming it rare. The *Wuzhen Pian* says: "Countless divine dragons are utterly astonished."]

Lü Dongbin, the Pure Yang Patriarch of the Five Chapters, embraced the origin and guarded the One, nurturing it for ten months—spirit took form, and he refined it. Facing the wall, he sat in oblivion, and after nine years, his body transcended form. [Note: The *Jindan Jieyao* states: "When the nation is prosperous and the people at peace, the Dao is already achieved—then one should face the wall to nurture the original spirit. When the nine transformations are complete, ascend to heaven, and forever become a Heavenly Immortal, enjoying boundless spring." After returning the elixir, one proceeds to nurture it. Embracing the original spirit and guarding the true One, the fire of the great celestial cycle must not be interrupted in the slightest. By the time the tenth month’s work is complete, a spirit emerges from the Mud Pill Palace above the crown, and a body exists beyond the body. The Ancestor of the Mud Pill Palace says: "In the tenth month, the fetal immortal emerges, borne by thunder and lightning as a golden dragon." "Refining the spirit" means that at every step, one must remain vigilant—this is the work of nursing, requiring three years. Thereafter, one selects an auspicious mountain, a blessed site, an ancient relic, or a numinous altar—where water encircles and mountains pay homage, where qi gathers and wind is stored. Beside the clouds, one constructs a chamber, sits in profound stillness, and forgets form. Form and spirit become wondrous, merging with the true Dao. Water and fire cannot harm, blades and weapons cannot injure. When merit is fulfilled in three thousand deeds and the time of nine years arrives, transformations become effortless, and the eight directions present no barrier. One may then move mountains and overturn seas, traverse earth and reach heaven, aid the world and pacify the people, punish the wicked and eliminate harm. Awaiting the celestial decree’s descent, one ascends in broad daylight, attaining the highest rank of Heavenly Immortals. Equal in grandeur to heaven and earth, in radiance to sun and moon, and in longevity to the cosmos, this is the supreme first vehicle.

The Great Dao of Heavenly Immortals is the work of true heroes—only the greatest of heroes and most extraordinary of talents may undertake it.

The inception of this Daoist art appears heterodox yet is fundamentally orthodox; within its firing process from beginning to end, it resembles the deployment of extraordinary military strategy.

At the outset of its practice, from the very first steps, there lies a wondrous technique for connecting with life and prolonging years. This art is profoundly esoteric—*The Awakening to Reality* states that it begins with deliberate action yet remains unseen by ordinary men. It belongs entirely to proper and orthodox practice, never licentious or absurd. *The Three-Character Formula* says:
*"Spoken, it is ugly;
Practiced, it is marvelous.
All despise it,
Each one mocks it."*
Bai Yuchan observes: *"Reveal it, and people will surely laugh."* *The Gourd Song* declares:
*"Practiced, it is marvelous;
Spoken, it is ugly—
Fools laugh till their mouths split."*
Though the words seem absurd and the deeds bizarre, who would not mistake it for heterodoxy?

As the saying goes:
*"The wicked practice orthodoxy, and even orthodoxy becomes wicked;
The upright practice heterodoxy, and even heterodoxy becomes upright."*
Yet the heart remains pure and undefiled, without the slightest impropriety—only the outward traces may seem suspicious.

As for the firing process: it begins with field combat and ends with defending the city. There are methods for achieving victory through surprise and images of battle and triumph. *The Rootless Tree* states: *"Dragon and tiger mount the altar for a single battle."* *The Awakening to Reality* says: *"In application, one must divide left and right armies—let them be the host while I remain the guest."* Bai Ziqing remarks: *"Only after the spiritual battle concludes can one behold the sage."* *"Heroes act in due time, and weapons secure great peace."*

Lead and mercury lack the Elder of Fire (Bing); east and west remain divided.
Infant and Maiden lack the Yellow Dame (Huangpo); though close as a foot and a span, they stand apart.

[Annotation: The Elder of Fire is fire. Refining lead and mercury cannot succeed without fire. The Wood-mercury of the east and the Metal-lead of the west are utterly estranged—only with the fire of bing and ding can they be harmonized, so that instead of mutual conquest, they give birth to one another. *The Awakening to Reality* states: *"Wood’s nature loves Metal’s righteous compliance; Metal’s disposition cherishes Wood’s benevolent kindness. Devouring each other, they grow intimate—only then does the man conceive."* *The Emerald Writ* says: *"Infant Boy and Maiden Girl are sundered as if by the ends of the earth; only by relying on the Yellow Dame to entwine them both."* *The Single Branch* says: *"Moved only when the Yellow Dame beckons, awaiting only when the Maiden opens her lotus."* *The Song of Tapping the Hexagrams* says: *"When the Yellow Dame matches them in perfect union, the moment is flawless, the transmission sealed."* *The Mirror for Taking the Medicine* says: *"Entrust the Yellow Dame to woo the Maiden Girl—lightly, silently, she lifts them together."* The Yellow Dame is the deputy marshal of the elixir chamber, utterly indispensable. Without her, though they stand as near as a foot and a span, their affinity is thwarted, their passions discordant, and they remain askew, unable to unite.]

Master the urgent and the gradual, weigh fortune and misfortune—all rests in the craftsman’s hand, to measure and deliberate.
Discern advance and retreat, know when to halt and when to be content—how could the ignorant ever succeed?

**[Annotation: The crux of elixir-refinement lies in the four characters—*gradual, urgent, auspicious, inauspicious*—which demand the most thorough familiarity and deliberation.
To *hold the city* is gradual; *field combat* is urgent.
*Tempering and nurturing* is gradual; *gathering the medicine* is urgent.
*Vital qi* is auspicious; *lethal qi* is inauspicious.
*Yang qi* is auspicious; *yin qi* is inauspicious.
*The Mirror for Taking the Medicine* says: *"Receive qi auspiciously, guard against its turning inauspicious."*
*The Waking to Reality* says: *"Hold the city or wage field combat—know fortune and misfortune, and you may fill the crucible with numinous cinnabar."*
Only when this is deeply understood and practiced with mastery may one be called a *craftsman’s hand*.
*To measure and deliberate* means to act with precision, never straying from the plumb line.
*The Rootless Tree* says: *"The craftsman’s hand, firm at the helm, lets the ocean’s waves churn below."*
*The Single Branch of Flowers* says: *"Wield the craftsman’s hand to sail upstream—such is the meaning here."*
Zhang Quanyi says: *"Yang fire advances, turning from the left; yin tally retreats, spiraling to the west."*
Master Qiu Changchun’s *Secret Formula of the Microcosmic Orbit* states: *"From Zi to Si, the six yang employ nine, thirty-six breaths to gather, take in, and ascend. From Wu to Hai, the six yin employ six, twenty-four breaths to retreat, descend, refine, and simmer."*
*Advance and retreat* are thus *ascent and descent*.
*The Orthodox Principle of Celestial Immortality* says: *"When the mechanism of inhalation closes, I turn to Qian, taking ascent as advance. When the mechanism of exhalation opens, I turn to Kun, taking descent as retreat."*
Master Chongxu says: *"Advance and retreat are but empty metaphors—truly, no advance or retreat is seen."*
Zhang Ziyang says:
*"Before refining the returning elixir, refine swiftly;
Once refined, know when to halt and be content.
If you cling to excess with an insatiable heart,
You will not escape ruin and disgrace one day."*
Xiao Liaozhen says: *"Beware—do not proceed with firing recklessly;
Without knowing when to halt, you court collapse and peril."*
This speaks of ceasing the fire once the elixir is formed—a principle of profound subtlety.
Without the true master’s direct instruction, even the brightest and wisest may struggle to comprehend it.
How could the ignorant ever succeed?]**

Recognize the ebb and flow as the tides of the sea, ever faithful to their time;
Gauge the workings of creation by the waxing and waning of the sun and moon.

[**Note:** The character *xin* (信, "faithfulness") is the grand path of all truth and sages. *Zhuangzi* says: *"There is sentiment, there is faithfulness; there is non-action, there is formlessness."* *The Hundred Verses* says: *"Within this lies true faithfulness—when it arrives, even the lord must be startled."* The midnight and noon never err; the tides keep their appointed hours. *The Mirror of Entering the Medicine* says: *"Heaven responds to the stars, earth responds to the tides."* Bai Yuchan says: *"Beneath the earth, the sea’s tides; above the sky, the moon."* *The Essential Instructions* says: *"When the time comes, await the tide’s sign—when the moon rises in the west."* By this, one measures faithfulness, and thus the principle of ebb and flow may be recognized at its source.

The sun and moon are the two luminaries of yin and yang. When qi issues forth as light, the moon borrows the sun’s radiance to shine. By the sun’s direct or slanted illumination, the moon’s spirit and body wax and wane. From this principle of waxing and waning, one may gauge the mechanism of creation.

On the third day, the moon emerges in the west—this is the first yang born in the Kan position. On the fifteenth, the moon is full in the east—then the six lines complete the Qian trigram’s primordial origin. [*The True Classic Song* says: *"On the third day, Zhen emerges in the west; by the winding river, the moon’s brilliance shines."* *The Union of the Three* says: *"On the third day, it emerges bright, Zhen receives the west; on the eighth, Dui receives the south, the upper arc straight as a cord; on the fifteenth, the Qian body is complete, full and flourishing in the east."* *The Awakening to Reality* says: *"On the southwestern path, the moon’s brilliance shines—from here the great medicine is born."* The great medicine is the returning first yang. This yang arises within the Kun body, emerging from pure yin. The full moon in the east: Qian contains *jia* and *ren*, Kun contains *yi* and *gui*; *jia*-wood and *geng*-metal face each other and become full. *The Union* says: *"When the three and five virtues are complete, the Qian body is formed, the six lines revolve in harmony."* *The Book of Changes* says: *"Transforming and moving without constraint, it flows through the six voids."* *The Union* says: *"Flowing through the six lines, it is difficult to perceive."* This describes how the two trigrams Qian and Kun revolve through the six trigrams, and how the central lines of Kan and Li revolve through the six lines. Qian and Kun give birth to the six children, each receiving one line from their central lines—thus it is said that without their central lines, they are incomplete.]

Split open the golden aperture, cleave the primordial chaos, revealing the innermost truths of Laozi and Zhuangzi;
Clarify the bellows and flute, drink the knife’s measure, spilling the heart and liver of Zhang Baiduan.

[**Note:** Unlocking the secret treasury of the golden lock, cleaving open the primordial chaos, one fully exposes the profound mechanisms of the *Daodejing* and *Nanhua*, the innermost truths of Laozi and Zhuangzi. The bellows and flute refer to the crucible. That with a base is the bellows; that without is the flute. The bellows of heaven and flute of earth are like the zither and flute, like the gourd. To drink the knife’s measure, first clarify the bellows and flute. *The Mirror of Entering the Medicine* says: *"Drink the knife’s measure, glimpse heaven’s art."* *The Union* says: *"Crush it into one pill—nothing is more divine than the knife’s measure."* The Perfected Zhang Baiduan, styled Pingshu, composed *The Awakening to Reality*, baring his liver and gall, spilling forth the true teachings.]

Thus enlightening the friends who wander amidst mist and clouds, unveiling the hidden secrets of dragon and tiger.

[Annotation: Among those who wander amidst mist and clouds, many possess enlightened talents. Those with the aspiration to cultivate the Dao yet lack the opportunity to receive its methods—by reading this rhapsody, their long-cherished resolve may be fulfilled, and their wisdom awakened. This is not merely an exercise in parallel prose, but a revelation of the true essence of the supreme Dao, an unveiling of the hidden principles of dragon and tiger.]

Each seeks the firing times, early to ingest the millet-pearl.
In the Jasper Pool’s mystic gardens, hope stirs for another day.

[Annotation: Those with resolve must each seek their own karmic conditions, practice the secrets of the firing times, and ingest the pearl of millet. The Jasper Pool’s mystic gardens, the three thousand weak waters—none but the flying immortals may reach them. Yet by cultivating in accord with this rhapsody, that hope shall not be difficult to attain. *The Union* says: *"Mount the white crane, ride the dragon’s scales; roam the Great Void, pay homage to the Immortal Lords. Receive the celestial chart, be named a Perfected One."* It also says: *"When the Great One summons, remove to the Central Continent. With merit complete, ascend on high, receive the register and chart."*]

Without thought, stillness may arise;
in stillness, qi finds its balance.
When qi is balanced, breath comes to rest;
when breath rests, it naturally returns to the root.
Returning to the root, one perceives original nature;
perceiving nature, one begins to be true.

[Those who cannot attain stillness are bound by thoughts. Before one thought subsides, another arises—ten thousand cares surge ceaselessly, without a moment’s respite from youth to old age. How rarely is even a single breath of clarity known? To cultivate stillness, first enter through the cessation of thought. When thoughts are exhausted, passions and desires dissolve, and the heart-mind becomes pure. With the heart-mind purified, qi naturally harmonizes, like fish in a spring pond, like insects in hibernation—steaming and unfolding in boundless subtlety, its qi balanced. Over time, the in-and-out breath stabilizes, returning to its root, and breathing ceases entirely. As the *Perfected One* dwells in the deep abyss, floating and roaming within the compass of the rule, in ceaseless continuity, utterly serene—this is qi returning to the central pole, revolving without end, not truly without breath. When breath returns to the root, stillness settles into quiescence. At the utmost point of quiescence, original nature manifests, and the light of wisdom arises spontaneously. Original nature is the primordial spirit of one’s true destiny. The Buddha said: *"Seeing nature, one becomes a Buddha—this is called attaining the Dao."* Yet there is nothing to attain; attaining nothingness is true attainment.]

The myriad beings bear no scent;
beneath the earth, one hears thunder roar.
Ascending to the summit of Kunlun,
the path behind must be kept clear.

[When all conditions are stilled and sounds and scents vanish into boundless obscurity, the moment of returning movement arrives—suddenly, thunder bursts forth from the earth. The *Alchemical Classic* says: *"Earth’s thunder shakes the mountain’s peak; rain washes the yellow sprout as it emerges from the soil."* This is true yang revealing itself, blazing like fire, raging like a scorching wind. The *Yellow Court Classic* says: *"Within is a true person, crowned in golden cloth, bearing armor and talismans to open the seven gates."* This is no branch or leaf—it is the root itself. At this time, the river chariot is set in motion, crossing the Tail Gate, passing the twin barriers of the Spine Pass, ascending the Jade Pillow to reach Kunlun. This is the work of rising behind and descending before—one must keep the path distinct, never hasty or careless.]

Descend the mountain to meet the Magpie Bridge,
escorting it down to the Yellow Court.
Within the court, the *Yi*’s hexagrams unfold—
fifty-five, perfectly balanced.

[The elixir, descending from the summit of Kunlun, hangs from the upper palate, crosses the Magpie Bridge, passes the Towering Chambers, and is escorted to the Yellow Court, where it comes to rest. The Yellow Court is the divine chamber of the central palace. At this time, wind stirs in the Mud Pill, the moon shines in the Crimson Palace, kidney qi ascends, sweet dew descends, and all is returned to the earthen cauldron—wind calms, waves still, the nation at peace, the people secure. *"Unfolding the hexagrams of the *Yi* within the court"* refers to the three hundred eighty-four lines of the hexagrams and the three hundred eighty-four grains of firing time, modeling Qian and Kun, pairing Kan and Li, moving water and fire—all this is the unfolding. The fifty-five: the heavenly number is five, the earthly number is five; the five positions interact and each finds its harmony. The heavenly numbers total twenty-five, the earthly numbers thirty. All the numbers of heaven and earth sum to fifty-five—this is how transformations are accomplished and the spirits are set in motion. *"Balanced"* means harmonious alignment, serving as the method for refining the elixir, teaching one to seek its image through heaven and earth.]

Qi rolls forth to fill the four great elements;
sit or lie—watch as you proceed.

This is the principle of foundation-laying—
lone yin cannot ascend.

*[The four great elements fill the body,
all is qi’s repletion, nowhere incomplete.
It rolls and unfurls with the times,
flowing through the four limbs—
the four limbs need no explanation.
"Sit or lie—watch as you proceed":
The* Jindan Jieyao *says:
"Two bodies sit facing, the two luminaries appear before you."
The* Zhixuan Pian *says:
"Together on the bed, build the ladder to heaven"—
this may be done sitting, or lying down as well.
This is the principle of foundation-laying:
know that lone yin does not generate,
solitary yang does not grow.
If one cultivates alone in stillness,
how can ascent and descent be achieved?]*

Next, forge the spirit-sword—
three years to refine the self and succeed.
Thoughts upright, passions forgotten utterly,
before the furnace, the spirit remains unmoved.

*[This sword is not cast of bronze or iron—
it is the sword of wisdom.
The alchemical classics say:
"Emerging from being, entering non-being—
the three-exhaustion sword;
the elixir of immortality—
a single pellet."
Those who refine the elixir
must first forge the sword
before they can gather the medicine.
Only when the work of refining the self is complete
may the elixir be returned.
Refining the self means:
upright thoughts present,
wayward intentions absent,
passions forgotten, forms transcended,
staking one’s life in the effort.
Before the furnace, when the work begins,
the primordial spirit remains unmoved,
the heart wholly devoted—
this is the work of refining the self,
this is the method of forging the sword.]*

Seek and purchase the vessels of the elixir chamber—
five thousand forty-eight springs.
First observe the third night of the month,
when the moth-browed moon first appears in the *geng* direction.

*[The vessels of the elixir chamber
are not easily obtained.
They must be bought with money,
sought with effort,
before they can be acquired.
These vessels must correspond
to the number of the* Zangzhen Jing*—
five thousand forty-eight scrolls.
Only this true classic
reveals, on the third night of each month,
a crescent moth-browed new moon
in the* geng *direction—
this is the radiance of golden essence,
the time when the great medicine is about to emerge.
The* Qinyuan Chun *says:
"The warm lead cauldron,
light piercing the curtains."
To witness the* geng *flower appear,
turn back to seek the moth-browed moon.
Thus gather true lead—
each word must be truly transmitted.
*[The patriarchs, in their compassion,
have directly revealed the celestial mechanism.
They say: If you wish to see the flower appear in the* geng *direction—
though its position lies in the west, the* geng *region—
you must in fact seek it within the body,
and at once behold the moth-browed new moon.
The alchemical classics say:
"Suddenly glimpsing a moon in the western quarter,
pure yang swiftly runs to report to Zhongli."
When the time arrives,
do not delay or hesitate—
missing the celestial mechanism
means losing this wondrous secret of gathering true lead.
It is not easily known,
not easily gathered.
From ancient times to the present,
it has been transmitted mouth to mouth,
never lightly bestowed.
The pearl in the robe is near at hand,
yet deluded ones waste their efforts—
all because they have not met a true teacher
or received the true transmission.]]*

The firing times begin on the first day—
one *liang* gradually grows.
On the sixteenth, withdraw the yin tally—
two *liang* show no further increase.

*[Fire has its proper timing;
await the moment and employ it—
the work must begin on the first day.
The* Cantong Qi *says:
"In the first year, the sprout nourishes."
The first year is the first day.
"One* liang *gradually grows"—
from the first day, accumulate the lines and grains.
The so-called "eight* liang *of lead,
half a* jin *of mercury"—
all are amassed by increments of weight.
The sixteenth is after the full moon;
the method calls for withdrawing the yin tally.
No further weight can be added—
this is the time to cease firing and halt the tally,
when the two no longer meet.]*

Bathing occurs at the hours of hare and fowl—
guard against loss, guard against peril and collapse.
Golden qi naturally steams and suffuses,
the body’s sweat dripping profusely.

*[Hare and fowl are* mao *and* you.
*Mao* is the hare among the twelve earthly branches,
*you* is the fowl.
At this time, punishment and virtue arrive at the gate—
the method calls for bathing.
Bathing means washing the heart and cleansing the thoughts.
The* Yi *says:
"The noble one washes the heart and retires, hidden in secrecy."
This matter is perilous—
above is heaven, below is hell.
One must proceed with utmost care,
guarding against collapse,
before the golden qi can steam and circulate,
rising and descending,
pervading the four limbs,
filling the entire body.
Warm qi harmonizes,
and sweat drips abundantly.]*

After ten months, the embryo is complete—
the crown of the head must release the spirit.
Then face the wall for nine years—
ascend to the Jade Capital in flight.

*[The* Cantong Qi *says:
"After ten months have passed,
it emerges from the womb."
When the ten months’ work is complete,
the nurturing is finished.
The alchemical classics say:
"Three hundred days of firing,
ten months of gestation—
the spirit leaves the body,
now here, now gone."
At this time, the ore is exhausted, the gold pure,
the entire body is pure yang.
The five viscera are regenerated,
the hundred bones re-established.
The mouth produces numinous fluid,
blood transforms into white marrow.
A thunderclap resounds,
golden light pierces the earth—
the infant emerges from the crown.
Gradually regulate the spirit,
slowly emerge from the shell.
Piercing metal and penetrating stone,
in an instant, ten thousand miles.
From this, a hundred thousand transformed bodies—
then proceed to face the wall and nurture emptiness.
After nine years, the work is complete,
the celestial decree descends,
the body flies to the golden palace—
this is what is meant by:
"After nine transformations, ascend to heaven,
forever a celestial immortal, living ten thousand springs."]*

Three stages of the work—
I have clearly explained them to you.
Now I personally unseal and release them,
composing this book to embody the secret method.

*[The work of refining the elixir has three stages.
The first barrier: refining the self and laying the foundation.
The middle barrier: refining qi to transform the spirit.
The upper barrier: refining the spirit to return to emptiness.
These three stages of the work
have never been spoken of by anyone in the past.
Now I have clearly revealed them,
personally unsealed and released them,
elaborating them into a book.
Those who are determined to pursue this Way
should embody and recognize the true secret,
practice it diligently,
and naturally enter the sage’s realm,
transcending the common herd.]*

Transmitted to the children of true refinement—
a method of gold and jade.
The elixir’s true secret is taught by the master—
it must be discussed with immortals.

Here is the translation:

---

Now, the secret method that has remained unspoken for ten thousand ages is revealed and compiled into this book, transmitted to the children of true refinement. This book is truly a golden and jade-like method, a precious raft for ascending the clouds. Yet, though this is its general outline, it is not easily heard. As for the mystery within the mystery, the subtlety within the subtlety, it must be received through the oral transmission of a true master. As the saying goes, "The true string must be taught by a true immortal." Common people, interpreting texts by their words alone, often err and mislead. Why not seek a master with resolve and spirit? In the end, you will surely encounter one. This is what is meant by *"You must discuss it carefully with immortals."*

There is yet another wondrous elixir method,
but I fear revealing too much would make it seem trivial.
It is like plucking the zither and striking the se,
husband and wife harmonizing their natures.

*[The profound and subtle mechanisms are not limited to one method. There is another elixir method, uniquely wondrous. Yet I fear revealing it entirely would cause those who hear it to dismiss its marvel. What is this method? It is the method of plucking the zither and striking the se. As the poem says: "When husband and wife are in harmony, it is like the zither and se played together." The zither is not played alone; the se must be struck in unison. In the Way of nature and emotion, harmony comes first, and mutual resonance follows. The *Canticle* says: "Push emotion to unite with nature, turning and joining together." How could the subtlety of the elixir method be easily understood?]*

Rosy light illumines the winding waters,
the red sun rises over Kunlun.
Vague and indistinct, dim and obscure—
within this, there is true certainty,
and when certainty arrives, you will surely be startled.

*[Metal and water shine brilliantly, wood and fire blaze red. The golden crow emerges from the sea, the jade hare ascends the sky. The sun rises in the east over Fusang, casting its glow upon the winding waters. The winding waters are the Qujiang River. The *Linjiang Immortal* says: "Upon Qujiang, the moon’s radiance is pure and bright, and there flies a crow." Laozi said: "Vague and indistinct, yet within it there is form; dim and obscure, yet within it there is essence. Its essence is utterly true, and within it there is certainty." Certainty means adherence to the unerring timing. "When certainty arrives, you will surely be startled" means that when the moment arrives, the wondrous principle manifests of itself, and the medicine’s emergence is divinely known. This vague indistinctness and dim obscurity describe the scene of obtaining the medicine—when the primordial qi arrives and the Supreme Ultimate begins to take shape.]*

A single drop like a vermilion orange,
it must be met by quicksilver.
No instruments are used at all—
the method inverts heaven and earth.

*[At the moment of the returning elixir, a visible form appears—a single drop falls into the Yellow Court, shaped like a vermilion orange or a pellet. Quicksilver is mercury. When the elixir arrives, one must move a drop of true mercury to receive it. Once it arrives, it becomes the master: the husband sings first, the wife follows after, inverting yin and yang, reversing the workings of creation. This is what is called "two layers of heaven and earth, four aspects of yin and yang." The *Three-Character Formula* says: "The great key lies in inversion: I become the guest, and it becomes the host." Instruments refer to the zither and sword. Once the elixir returns to the crucible and the tally is complete, the fire is stilled—no instruments are used, only this wondrous mechanism. Countless learners in the world—how could they number less than ten thousand times ten thousand? Yet who truly knows? Knowing is not difficult; what matters is accumulating abundant merit and performing acts of kindness. Where your resolve lies, heaven will respond, and immortals will surely become your teachers.]*

The world does not understand the principle,
practicing the Three Peaks’ sexual arts,
some speak of the Three Passes,
others enter the furnace and face the moment—
even mouth-to-mouth,
filthy and unbearable to hear.
All conditioned methods
are the people of hell.

*[The world, failing to grasp the profound principle, sees in the elixir scriptures phrases like "mouth to mouth, aperture to aperture, do not disdain the filth, do not calculate the cost," and guesses it refers to the female crucible, practicing the Three Peaks’ sexual arts, the method of nine shallow and one deep. They beautify it with names like "Pengzu’s bedchamber arts." Some speak of the Three Passes—rear upper, front lower—while others engage in inner alchemy with women, facing the furnace and consuming filth, mouth-to-mouth. How vile and unbearable! All such side doors are this filthy and foul. They are all seeds of hell, beyond salvation. True masters are hard to meet, true methods hard to obtain. Those with resolve should diligently accumulate virtue.]*

There are those who cling stubbornly,
believing dead stillness to be true.
Their hair turns yellow, their teeth fall out,
their bodies like magpies, their forms like cranes.

*[Some fools, stubborn and unyielding, cling rigidly to stillness, believing it to be the unshakable truth. They practice bitter austerities, sitting day and night, causing their qi and blood to stagnate. Their bodies become like magpies, their forms like cranes, emaciated as sticks. Even when their hair turns yellow and their teeth fall out, they still do not awaken—how lamentable! The reason for this is that people commonly see Daoist practitioners as unmarried and unofficed, sitting alone in remote mountains, dwelling deep in valleys, empty and desiccated in their stillness, calling it "cultivating the truth." They also see in novels that entering the mountains to cultivate the Dao means becoming an immortal. How could they know that sitting until old age and death is all in vain? Ultimately, this comes from not carefully reading the elixir scriptures. When Zhang Sanfeng met the Fire Dragon Immortal, he was given a secret method and told to leave the mountains quickly to seek karmic conditions. Thus, *A Branch of Flowers* says: "I was commanded to leave the mountains, to seek companions and find lead." The Stone Immortal of Apricot Grove told Xue Zixian: "Go to the bustling cities and rely on those with power to assist you." Since ancient times, true immortals have all emerged from among people, sought from among the wealthy and powerful. The ancients had to leave the mountains, yet people today insist on entering them; the ancients all worked through action, yet people today only speak of non-doing. So many contradictions, running counter to the Dao. Stubbornly clinging to dead stillness, they die without regret. Why not read the *Scripture of Purity and Stillness*, which says: "Such purity and stillness gradually enter the true Dao; though it is called attaining the Dao, in reality, nothing is attained."]*

To transform sentient beings—this is called attaining the Dao. The text elaborates at length, reaching the utmost purity and stillness, yet suddenly appends a line: "Those who awaken to this may transmit the sacred Dao." Even at such purity and stillness, there is still transmission—why do people remain so unaware? In short, they are accustomed to the common principles of the human world and fail to witness the marvels of sages and spirits; this again hinges on the depth or shallowness of one’s innate capacity.

mistaking the false for true.
Observe heaven’s great Dao,
grasp heaven’s great workings.

The movements of heaven and earth, sun and moon, the wondrous functions of Kan and Li in the body, the four cardinal gates of mystery—who truly understands these?"]

The moon hangs over the western river,
rosy clouds touch the southern shores.
Three days before is the dark of the moon—
pure yin within yang.

[Annotation: "The moon hangs over the western river" depicts the white moon atop the mountain, an image of fresh, tender medicinal sprouts. "Rosy clouds touch the southern shores" shows the red sun at the pool’s bottom, an image of vanquished yin demons. *Awakening to Reality* says: "On the southwestern path, the moon’s brilliance shines—great medicine arises from this place." The western river is where lead is produced; the southern Li is the source of fire. "Three days before" refers to the three days prior to *geng*. The "dark of the moon" is the day before the new moon. Thus, "three days before is the dark" signifies the moment before the living *zi* hour, the end of *hai*. yang essence within yin.
Just as winter solstice arrives,
harmonious scenes herald a fine spring.

[Annotation: "Three days after" refers to the three days following *jia*, when the dark of the moon ends and the new moon begins, the transition from the end of *hai* to the start of *zi*. At this moment, yin reaches its extreme and yang is born, a single yang rising from beneath the ninefold earth—akin to the seasonal winter solstice. When yang returns, the great earth becomes spring, radiant with vibrant light and vitality. Three hundred sixty joints, eighty-four thousand pores—all melt into harmony, a sweet, unbounded ease, the whole body bathed in spring.]

The eighth day is the first quarter,
inquire at the rabbit’s gate of *mao*.
The sixteenth is the beginning of *gou*,
the twenty-third is the gate of *you*.
Through this, examine the *Yi* hexagrams—
only then can you know the true Great Dao.

[Annotation: The new moon’s first quarter occurs on the eighth day of the month; the waning moon’s last quarter, on the twenty-third. *Mao* belongs to the rabbit, *you* to the rooster.
