Now, the secret method that has remained unspoken for ten thousand ages is revealed and compiled into this book, transmitted to the children of true refinement. This book is truly a golden and jade-like method, a precious raft for ascending the clouds. Yet, though this is its general outline, it is not easily heard. As for the mystery within the mystery, the subtlety within the subtlety, it must be received through the oral transmission of a true master. As the saying goes, "The true string must be taught by a true immortal." Common people, interpreting texts by their words alone, often err and mislead. Why not seek a master with resolve and spirit? In the end, you will surely encounter one. This is what is meant by *"You must discuss it carefully with immortals."*

There is yet another wondrous elixir method,
but I fear revealing too much would make it seem trivial.
It is like plucking the zither and striking the se,
husband and wife harmonizing their natures.

*[The profound and subtle mechanisms are not limited to one method. There is another elixir method, uniquely wondrous. Yet I fear revealing it entirely would cause those who hear it to dismiss its marvel. What is this method? It is the method of plucking the zither and striking the se. As the poem says: "When husband and wife are in harmony, it is like the zither and se played together." The zither is not played alone; the se must be struck in unison. In the Way of nature and emotion, harmony comes first, and mutual resonance follows. The *Canticle* says: "Push emotion to unite with nature, turning and joining together." How could the subtlety of the elixir method be easily understood?]*

Rosy light illumines the winding waters,
the red sun rises over Kunlun.
Vague and indistinct, dim and obscure—
within this, there is true certainty,
and when certainty arrives, you will surely be startled.

*[Metal and water shine brilliantly, wood and fire blaze red. The golden crow emerges from the sea, the jade hare ascends the sky. The sun rises in the east over Fusang, casting its glow upon the winding waters. The winding waters are the Qujiang River. The *Linjiang Immortal* says: "Upon Qujiang, the moon’s radiance is pure and bright, and there flies a crow." Laozi said: "Vague and indistinct, yet within it there is form; dim and obscure, yet within it there is essence. Its essence is utterly true, and within it there is certainty." Certainty means adherence to the unerring timing. "When certainty arrives, you will surely be startled" means that when the moment arrives, the wondrous principle manifests of itself, and the medicine’s emergence is divinely known. This vague indistinctness and dim obscurity describe the scene of obtaining the medicine—when the primordial qi arrives and the Supreme Ultimate begins to take shape.]*

A single drop like a vermilion orange,
it must be met by quicksilver.
No instruments are used at all—
the method inverts heaven and earth.

*[At the moment of the returning elixir, a visible form appears—a single drop falls into the Yellow Court, shaped like a vermilion orange or a pellet. Quicksilver is mercury. When the elixir arrives, one must move a drop of true mercury to receive it. Once it arrives, it becomes the master: the husband sings first, the wife follows after, inverting yin and yang, reversing the workings of creation. This is what is called "two layers of heaven and earth, four aspects of yin and yang." The *Three-Character Formula* says: "The great key lies in inversion: I become the guest, and it becomes the host." Instruments refer to the zither and sword. Once the elixir returns to the crucible and the tally is complete, the fire is stilled—no instruments are used, only this wondrous mechanism. Countless learners in the world—how could they number less than ten thousand times ten thousand? Yet who truly knows? Knowing is not difficult; what matters is accumulating abundant merit and performing acts of kindness. Where your resolve lies, heaven will respond, and immortals will surely become your teachers.]*

The world does not understand the principle,
practicing the Three Peaks’ sexual arts,
some speak of the Three Passes,
others enter the furnace and face the moment—
even mouth-to-mouth,
filthy and unbearable to hear.
All conditioned methods
are the people of hell.

*[The world, failing to grasp the profound principle, sees in the elixir scriptures phrases like "mouth to mouth, aperture to aperture, do not disdain the filth, do not calculate the cost," and guesses it refers to the female crucible, practicing the Three Peaks’ sexual arts, the method of nine shallow and one deep. They beautify it with names like "Pengzu’s bedchamber arts." Some speak of the Three Passes—rear upper, front lower—while others engage in inner alchemy with women, facing the furnace and consuming filth, mouth-to-mouth. How vile and unbearable! All such side doors are this filthy and foul. They are all seeds of hell, beyond salvation. True masters are hard to meet, true methods hard to obtain. Those with resolve should diligently accumulate virtue.]*

There are those who cling stubbornly,
believing dead stillness to be true.
Their hair turns yellow, their teeth fall out,
their bodies like magpies, their forms like cranes.

*[Some fools, stubborn and unyielding, cling rigidly to stillness, believing it to be the unshakable truth. They practice bitter austerities, sitting day and night, causing their qi and blood to stagnate. Their bodies become like magpies, their forms like cranes, emaciated as sticks. Even when their hair turns yellow and their teeth fall out, they still do not awaken—how lamentable! The reason for this is that people commonly see Daoist practitioners as unmarried and unofficed, sitting alone in remote mountains, dwelling deep in valleys, empty and desiccated in their stillness, calling it "cultivating the truth." They also see in novels that entering the mountains to cultivate the Dao means becoming an immortal. How could they know that sitting until old age and death is all in vain? Ultimately, this comes from not carefully reading the elixir scriptures. When Zhang Sanfeng met the Fire Dragon Immortal, he was given a secret method and told to leave the mountains quickly to seek karmic conditions. Thus, *A Branch of Flowers* says: "I was commanded to leave the mountains, to seek companions and find lead." The Stone Immortal of Apricot Grove told Xue Zixian: "Go to the bustling cities and rely on those with power to assist you." Since ancient times, true immortals have all emerged from among people, sought from among the wealthy and powerful. The ancients had to leave the mountains, yet people today insist on entering them; the ancients all worked through action, yet people today only speak of non-doing. So many contradictions, running counter to the Dao. Stubbornly clinging to dead stillness, they die without regret. Why not read the *Scripture of Purity and Stillness*, which says: "Such purity and stillness gradually enter the true Dao; though it is called attaining the Dao, in reality, nothing is attained."]*

To transform sentient beings—this is called attaining the Dao. The text elaborates at length, reaching the utmost purity and stillness, yet suddenly appends a line: "Those who awaken to this may transmit the sacred Dao." Even at such purity and stillness, there is still transmission—why do people remain so unaware? In short, they are accustomed to the common principles of the human world and fail to witness the marvels of sages and spirits; this again hinges on the depth or shallowness of one’s innate capacity.

---
He knows not our Dao,
mistaking the false for true.
Observe heaven’s great Dao,
grasp heaven’s great workings.

[Annotation: All heterodox schools cling rigidly to their own views. How could they know the subtlety of our Dao—borrowing the false to cultivate the true, turning the false into the real? The *Scripture of Unconscious Unison* says: "Observe heaven’s Dao, grasp heaven’s workings—this is perfection." Heaven and earth form one great yin-yang; the human body, one small yin-yang. The heavens have Greater Yin and Greater Yang; the body, Lesser Yin and Lesser Yang—their principles are identical. The scripture states: "Simply focus the heart on emulating heaven. The movements of heaven and earth, sun and moon, the wondrous functions of Kan and Li in the body, the four cardinal gates of mystery—who truly understands these?"]

---
The moon hangs over the western river,
rosy clouds touch the southern shores.
Three days before is the dark of the moon—
pure yin within yang.

[Annotation: "The moon hangs over the western river" depicts the white moon atop the mountain, an image of fresh, tender medicinal sprouts. "Rosy clouds touch the southern shores" shows the red sun at the pool’s bottom, an image of vanquished yin demons. *Awakening to Reality* says: "On the southwestern path, the moon’s brilliance shines—great medicine arises from this place." The western river is where lead is produced; the southern Li is the source of fire. "Three days before" refers to the three days prior to *geng*. The "dark of the moon" is the day before the new moon. Thus, "three days before is the dark" signifies the moment before the living *zi* hour, the end of *hai*. At this time, the great medicine is about to emerge—what is called "the appearance of lead’s light three days prior" occurs precisely at the height of yin.]

---
Three days after is the new moon—
yang essence within yin.
Just as winter solstice arrives,
harmonious scenes herald a fine spring.

[Annotation: "Three days after" refers to the three days following *jia*, when the dark of the moon ends and the new moon begins, the transition from the end of *hai* to the start of *zi*. At this moment, yin reaches its extreme and yang is born, a single yang rising from beneath the ninefold earth—akin to the seasonal winter solstice. The winter solstice is heaven and earth’s true *zi* hour; the "yang essence" is the body’s living *zi* hour. When yang returns, the great earth becomes spring, radiant with vibrant light and vitality. The arrival of true yang in the body is like the sun rising over Fusang, its crimson glow suffusing the earth. Three hundred sixty joints, eighty-four thousand pores—all melt into harmony, a sweet, unbounded ease, the whole body bathed in spring.]

---
The eighth day is the first quarter,
inquire at the rabbit’s gate of *mao*.
The sixteenth is the beginning of *gou*,
the twenty-third is the gate of *you*.
Through this, examine the *Yi* hexagrams—
only then can you know the true Great Dao.

[Annotation: The new moon’s first quarter occurs on the eighth day of the month; the waning moon’s last quarter, on the twenty-third. *Mao* belongs to the rabbit, *you* to the rooster. These two hours are the gates of punishment and virtue, the moments of bathing—know that bathing at *mao* benefits mercury, while bathing at *you* benefits lead. The third day of the new moon marks the first return of a single yang; after the sixteenth day of the full moon, a single yin begins to *gou*. *The Union* says: "On the eighth day, *dui* receives *ding*, the first quarter level as a string; on the fifteenth, the *qian* body is complete, fullness in *jia* to the east; on the sixteenth, the mandate shifts, *xun*’s *xin* appears at dawn; *gen* aligns with *bing* to the south, the last quarter on the twenty-third." Scholars who study this principle and examine the *Yi* hexagrams will recognize that the Great Dao possesses its own truth—it cannot be falsified.]

---
A hundred verses in this chapter,
each word demands careful study.
This book is guarded by thunder gods—
those who obtain it must not treat it lightly.

[Annotation: This book contains one hundred verses. Within these hundred verses—five hundred characters in all—each is a luminous pearl, every word profoundly subtle. Scholars must seek the text’s meaning, ponder its phrases, and silently grasp its principles. To transcend the ordinary and become a sage, to hold the secret and mysterious mechanism—this is what heaven treasures. This chapter reveals the celestial mechanism in full, and thunder spirits guard this true formula. Readers must not dismiss it as mere casual speech. Revere it—do not neglect!]

**III. The Song of the True Scripture**

The Song of the True Scripture, the Song of the True Scripture—
those who fail to recognize the True Scripture are all possessed by demons.
Each person seeks meaning in the written word,
and many chant ceaselessly without end.

[Annotation: *True* is spoken in contrast to *false*. The *True Scripture* is the scripture of cultivating the True. In truth, the True Scripture has no written form—it exists before the primal chaos, before the beginning of the dark and yellow, before the Supreme Ultimate, as the ancestor of primordial qi. All heavenly immortals and buddhas: in their coming, none could enter the world without this scripture; in their going, none could leave the world without it. It is the root-source that gives birth to heaven and earth, to humans and the myriad things. Immortals and buddhas refine it to ascend; ghosts and spirits exist because of it. The sacred assemblies of the numinous altars, the blessed lands of the grotto-heavens—all are shaped by the True Governor of creation. The ten thousand affairs and principles of the world, the forms that arise from nonbeing, the qi that dissolves into being—none do not emerge from it. Great indeed is the True Scripture! It is beyond conception, beyond naming.

The common person uses it to bear sons and raise daughters, cherishing it as a trifle; the perfected one uses it to extend life and attain the True, treasuring it as sacred. This thing is abundant—whether in foreign lands or China, regardless of wealth or poverty, it fills the earth without exception. It is the blue sky beneath the roof, the living path before one’s eyes. Yet without a true teacher’s guidance, none can know its wondrous use.

People, failing to recognize its wondrous use, thus fall entirely into demonic paths—such as swallowing cinnabar and consuming filth, or engaging in sexual arts with women. These are the seeds of hell, deeds that prevent rebirth for ten thousand kalpas. Why do they enter these demonic ranks and suffer such demonic obstructions? Only because they do not recognize the True Scripture.

There are those who rely on textual exegesis, seeking profound principles solely in words and phrases, probing the trigrams for symbolic meanings, chanting endlessly—yet they remain a thousand miles from the Dao.]

Holding scriptures and incantations, reciting ritual codes,
arranging them on paper in hope of liberation—
if such means could transcend life and death,
then every monk on earth would become a buddha.

[Annotation: Holding incantations and reciting scriptures, following ritual procedures, seeking liberation solely through words and texts—this is to assume the true formula lies on paper. If such practices could free one from the sea of suffering, transcend the ordinary, and enter sagehood, resolving the great matter of life and death, then all beings on earth, and the countless monks who chant scriptures and incantations, would have long since become buddhas. Yet since ancient times, none have attained immortality or buddhahood through mere recitation—thus, the true path must lie elsewhere.]

Obtain the True Scripture, and emerge from the vast waves;
without the True Scripture, there is no recourse.
If you ask where the True Scripture truly lies—
in the primordial creation, nothing more.

[Annotation: The above passages allude to the scripture’s name and meaning; only now is its wondrous nature directly revealed. This True Scripture is most difficult to obtain. If one gains it, one may escape the vast waves. People drift in the sea of suffering, tossed by the currents without end. This scripture is the precious raft of the vast waves, the compassionate ferry to the other shore. Without it, there is truly no method—what can one do about these vast waves?

If one asks where the true and wondrous essence of this scripture lies, it is simply in seeking the primordial creation, the authentic mechanism of the mysterious. Its principle is most subtle, its practice most simple—there is truly nothing more to it.]

To follow the flow is death, to reverse the course is life—yet often you seek in vain.
The True Scripture originally bears not a single word,
yet it can ferry all beings beyond the Great Veil.

Dao of immortals and Dao of humanity differ only in following or reversing;
thus the *Yi* speaks of "reversing the reckoning."
To follow is to generate humans and creatures;
to reverse is to become immortal or Buddha.
It is also said: the Five Phases flowing forward make a fiery pit of the dharma-realm;
the Five Phases flowing in reverse bring undying longevity.
The human path begins with an initial spark,
proceeds to a wailing cry at birth,
then infancy, childhood, youth, maturity, old age, and death—
this is the forward flow of conditioned existence.
The immortal path returns from old age to youth,
then to the fetal state, to the Supreme Ultimate, to the Ultimateless—
this is the reverse flow of unconditioned existence.
Ten thousand volumes of alchemical scriptures speak only of principle.
Hence it is said: "Because alchemical scriptures lack oral instructions,
where can you form the numinous embryo?"
Though reversal may bring life,
its method is not transmitted,
often leaving seekers groping in the dark, unable to find it.
Know that this scripture is not a scripture of written words,
but the tides of the great ocean, where the moon never misses its appointed time.
As the *Cantong Qi* says: "Revolving through the twelve nodes,
when one cycle ends, you must draw near again."
This scripture alone can deliver all beings,
ascending them to the realm of the Three Pure Ones in the Great Veil.

To obtain the True Scripture and deliver yourself,
nothing suffices but the harmony of two like kinds.
Whether generating heaven, earth, or humanity,
how could it depart from the nest of yin-yang transformation?

The True Scripture’s secrets are not easily heard.
Out of compassion, the Patriarch speaks plainly to you, ordinary beings:
if you seek the True Scripture to deliver yourself,
I now directly point it out to you—
nothing suffices but the use of like kinds in mutual harmony.
Who, then, is the counterpart?
As the Patriarch does not fail to say:
"A broken pot must be mended with iron,
tattered clothes must be held together with cloth.
If a person’s vitality is damaged yet lacks the true golden qi,
how could one in ten thousand ever revive?"
The *Wuzhen Pian* says:
"A broken bamboo must be mended with bamboo,
to hatch a chick you must use an egg.
All efforts with unlike kinds are wasted labor—
how could they compare to true lead uniting with the sacred mechanism?"
It also says:
"Tattered clothes must be mended with cloth,
a weakened person must be restored with lead."
The *Cantong Qi* says:
"To prepare the elixir of immortality,
you must use substances of the same kind."
And again:
"Like kinds are easily worked,
unlike kinds cannot be skillfully employed.
Only like kinds follow one another—
without this, the work will not yield treasure."
Thus swallows do not hatch phoenixes,
foxes and hares do not nurse foals—
because they are not of the same kind.
Since it is called "like kinds" and "mutual harmony,"
the meaning is clear—what further doubt could there be?
If cultivators of the Dao truly seek by means of like kinds,
the qi of wondrous transformation will naturally arise.
This is how humanity is generated,
and how heaven, earth, and the myriad things are generated.
The *Lingbao Bifa* says:
"The Dao-qi resides entirely within the human body,
able to transform and generate all heavens,
illuminating the Three Luminaries."
Yin and yang are themselves like kinds;
only with yin and yang does transformation arise.
When transformation is spoken of as a "nest,"
there must be an aperture within it.

On the third day, the *Zhen* trigram emerges with *geng*,
above the Winding River, the moon’s radiance gleams bright.
Flower buds just unfurl, bearing pearls of dew;
in tiger’s den and dragon’s lair, one probes the turbid and the clear.

Water begets two, the elixir is true—
wait for three, and it cannot advance.
*Ren*-water first arrives, *gui* has yet to come:
swiftly gather it, discerning its rise and fall.

The golden crucible refines, the jade furnace smelts,
with gentle, warming embers, softly glowing.
The true scripture pierces the Mysterious Pass in a single shot,
like an arrow striking the red center of the target.

The body grows hot, as if steamed in a basket;
turning the light inward, it illumines the Central Palace.
Once the true scripture is attained, one is drunk as with wine—
breath and pulse return to their root, all hundred channels restored.

Essence enters *qi*, *qi* transforms into spirit;
after seven days in chaos, the soul returns anew.
Such is the true workings of creation’s message—
how few in the world dare to speak of it.

Alive within death, dead yet reborn:
since ancient times, immortals and buddhas have relied on the true scripture.
Whoever grasps this work of creation
shall ferry all beings across the Jambu continent.

And it further states:
*"Sentient beings descend to sow the seed,
By cause in the ground, the fruit is born again;
The insentient are of five kinds,
Without nature, they too are unborn."*

As in the Dragon Girl offering the pearl,
the earth surging with golden lotuses,
the earth surging with the jeweled pagoda,
or the perfection of the Tathāgata’s *māraṇa-guhya* form—
are these different from what is not different?
Yet today’s monks rarely engage in true cultivation.
The patriarchs, in their compassion, have all pointed this out.

If one can know this true scripture and practice this work of creation,
though the Jambu continent be vast, all may at once become immortals and buddhas.
The scripture says:
*"Were the common folk all to know this,
the world’s immortals would flow like water."*

The Great Dao abides first in the Supreme Ultimate,
originating before father and mother.
To ferry others, one must ferry them with the true scripture—
if asked what the true scripture is, *gui* is lead.

**[Annotation:**
Beyond the Supreme Ultimate lies the source of the Great Dao,
before father and mother.
As the *Cantong Qi* says: *"Original essence spreads like clouds,
borne by qi at the beginning."*
The patriarchs say: *"Exhaustively seek the moment of receiving qi at birth."*
Before birth, it is not like the Buddhists’ discourse on emptiness
or awakening to the absence of self—
one must awaken to the very inception of the self.

To ferry others, one must ferry them with the true scripture;
there is no other method besides this.
Knowing this scripture, the crucible, furnace, talismans, and fire
are all contained within it.
The Celestial Root and the Moon Cavern all arise from this.

If one asks what the true scripture is—
lead is *gui*, and *gui* is the scripture.
Compassion, compassion! I would weep,
weeping for all the aspirants in the world who fall short of their aim.

In vain they endure hardship, stubbornly sit in meditation,
failing to meet the right conditions,
suffering a lifetime of toil,
only to grow old without achievement—how pitiful!
Refining the mortal to enter sagehood is the greatest of matters,
rarely encountered in a lifetime.

May the worthy and wise of the world
broadly sow fields of merit,
cultivate hidden virtues,
seek a teacher to reveal the lead within water—
naturally, understanding one thing will open a hundred,
resolving one will settle all,
and one shall become true.
**]**

The crucible is none other than the body of Heaven and Earth,
the great elixir is nothing but essence, qi, and spirit.
If you can gather and refine them into one,

Three people—no other way—
only with a true teacher and true oral instructions,
who reveals the three-grade elixir of yin and yang,

Await the bright moon, yet do not delay:
gather body and mind to first lay the foundation.
Split open the dust-laden heart, cast off the karmic net,
expel the five leakages, slay the three corpses.

Slay the three corpses, and the sword is forged;
refine the self to attain numinous knowing—then the signs appear.

chunks.translated_text:
**IV. The Crucible’s Song (continued)**

With hardness and softness transformed at will,
you drive away demons for ten thousand leagues swift as lightning.
*[Note: The three corpses are spirits dwelling in the flesh and blood of the human body. They do not wish for human life but thrive on human death. Whenever one acts recklessly in anger or surrenders to lust without restraint, it is these spirits that secretly stoke the fire, stirring chaos to overturn one’s resolve—hence the inevitable regret afterward. These corpses are the greatest hindrance to the Dao. The upper corpse resides in the brain, the middle in the abdomen, and the lower in the kidneys—collectively known as the Three Peng. Those who cultivate the Dao must first slay the three corpses. As *The Wuzhen Pian* states: "Only when the three corpses are slain can the Dao be attained." Yet they cannot be severed by blades of bronze or iron; only the sword of wisdom can seal the leaks. This sword is possessed by all, though few are willing to wield it. Forged by intent and wielded without form, it aids in refining the self until, over time, numinous resonance arises. Able to be firm or yielding, to bend or extend, it transforms at the heart’s command, driving away demons for ten thousand leagues with the speed of lightning.]*

Swift as lightning, the sword gains its numinous power,
then hang it in the south to guard the crystal waters.
Should yin ghosts rise from the north,
a single stroke severs all without mercy.
*[Note: Only when the sword moves like lightning is it called "numinous." It is hung in the south—the position of *li* (fire). The "crystal waters" signify a heart as clear as water. Without mercy, abide in constant clarity,
the heart’s purity gleaming like a bright mirror.
When the mirror-heart is extinguished, still as empty space,
only then can you face the crucible without flaw.

harmonize the cauldron’s vessel without haste.

only when dragon rises and tiger thrives can the work begin.

chunks.original_text: 通语言，作眷属，要待龙虎兴旺，始而驱龙就虎，继而即虎擒龙。 苟非二物兴旺之候，不可妄为，旺则堪图也。 】 始堪图，观复作，凿开混沌鸿蒙窍。 静观虎啸与龙吟，自然华池神水到。 【注：炼丹必待龙兴虎旺，始有来复之机。 《易》曰：复其见天地之心。 邵子谓：冬至子之半，天心无改移。 一阳初动处万物未生时。 此际正是先天太极，杳冥恍惚之际，亦如混沌初开，鸿蒙乍启。 夫此鸿蒙之窍，谁为凿开端在真师传授之的。 龙虎一交，风云际会，凝神入气穴而观之，玄黄立战化作天地之髓，此髓便是神水华池，自然而然，一时都到。 所谓只要神水入华池者此也。 】 神水到，辨浮沉，莫教时过枉劳心。 铅遇癸生须急采，金逢望远不堪亲。 【注：神水者真铅也。 先辨浮沉，次明主客，然后测海潮，听消息。 此时一刻万金，切勿当面错过，致令枉用心机。 采真铅者。 以何为候当癸生之时，急用采工。 此时阴极阳生，如初三之月，渐次生明，至望值金精盛极。 若至望远，则铅已成质，不堪采取矣。 亲者亲近之也。 】 不堪亲，休乱取，地裂山崩难作主。 不知止足必倾危，盛夏严霜冬大暑。 【注：不堪亲者，时已过也。 便当止火，勿行采取之工。 倘胡乱行为，必致炉残鼎败，龙散虎哮，不自主持矣。 须知止火有定则。 经曰：知足不辱，知止不殆。 若也持盈未已，必遭倾覆，而取殆辱矣。 《契》曰； 纤芥不正，悔吝为贼。 隆冬大暑，盛夏雪霜。 天见其怪，山崩地裂。 可不慎与 】 冬大暑，不遭逢，三宝牢关密守中。 太极自然生造化，趁时搬驭人黄宫。 【注：盛夏严霜，隆冬大暑，须要谨慎，切勿遭逢。 三宝者，耳目口。 《契》曰：耳目口三宝，闭塞勿发通，真人潜深渊，浮游守规中。 老子曰：多言数穷，不如守中。 果能守中绝学，抱一无言，太极亟三，自然生出造化。 惟此造化窟中，自然产出大药。 时节一到，大用现前，急备搬腾，猛加抽添，驾动河车，由天谷泥丸，运入黄宫。 黄宫者，中央土釜，即黄庭也。 】 入黄宫，须爱护。
chunks.translated_text:
To commune in speech is to become kin,
yet one must await the thriving of dragon and tiger—
only then may the dragon be driven to the tiger,
and in turn, the tiger seize the dragon.
If the moment of their flourishing has not arrived,
do not act recklessly, for only in their vigor may the work begin.

Once the work may begin, observe the return,
and hew open the aperture of primordial chaos.
Watch in stillness the tiger’s roar and the dragon’s song,
and naturally the divine water of the Flowery Pond will arrive.

When the divine water arrives, discern its rising and sinking,
lest the hour pass and your efforts be in vain.
When lead meets the birth of *gui*, hasten to gather it;
when gold nears its fullness, it is no longer fit for intimacy.

If unfit for intimacy, do not recklessly take—
earth will split and mountains crumble, and you will lose control.
He who knows not when to cease courts peril;
in midsummer, bitter frost; in deep winter, scorching heat.

If scorching winter is not encountered,
guard the Three Treasures within the firm pass.
The Great Ultimate naturally generates transformation—
seize the moment to guide and convey it into the Yellow Palace.

Entering the Yellow Palace, tend it with care.

chunks.original_text: 十月浇淋休失误。 子行阳火虎龙交，午退阴符自保固。 【注：中央神室，谓之黄庭。 丹既入此，谓之神丹入鼎。 《悟真篇》曰：“送归土釜牢封固”是也。 从此浇培，行大周天之火候，依前子进阳火，午退阴符。 阳火进而虎龙交，阴符退则自保固。 此并行独行之分界，不遇真师，何由得解】 自保固，暂相离，端坐忘言更待时，辐辏循环终则始，三百六十莫违期。 【注：独自保固，龙虎分交，暂时离异。 《契》曰：内以养己，安静虚无。 即端坐忘言之义。 更待时者，《无根树》曰：卸了重开有定期。 契曰“周旋十二节，节尽更须亲”。 如辐之辏毂，循环不穷，终则复始。 三百六十者，乾坤一卦之总数也。 乾之数，二百一十有六； 坤之数，百四十有四。 子行三十六，积得阳爻一百八十数； 午行二十四，合得阴符一百二十数，此阳爻用九，四九三十六也； 阴爻用六，四六二十四也。 除卯酉沐浴不在内，此周天之数，为妙用之程限者，不可不知。 】 莫违期，为则例，悟明真理须当契。 若还执着爻象行，只恐劳神形蠹弊。 【注：莫违期，刻定期限，不可移易。 准为则例，欲修妙道，先契妙机。 此个真机，须要契合，切勿执着。 若不悟彻玄微，执文泥象，数刻漏，按爻铢，形弊神劳，到老无成，空自费力。 此皆不悟玄中至理，讹舛谬误，自作聪明，到老无成。 当知此事，非真师指点，万无一是。 】 形蠹弊，往来坚，只恐心机未得闲。 思虑慕真毫发错，铅消汞散不成丹。 【注：往来者，小往大来之功，进退是也。 世人到身形蠹弊，老髦不堪。 若能行此往来之功，自然日见坚强，日有效验。 所以不能行此者，为方寸无定，万虑千愁不得一刻宁止。 夫炼铅烹汞，全在心静神闲。 毫髦思虑，便是差错。 《入药镜》曰：差毫发，不成丹。 《悟真篇》曰：毫发差殊不作丹，此之谓也。 】 不成丹，思炼己，皆因失却玄中理。 水干火燥要调停，刑德临门知进退。 【注：丹之不成，总由炼己不熟。 昔人谓炼己未熟； 不敢还丹。 炼己之功大矣哉。 又曰：修仙有程，炼己无限。 炼己二字，是修丹之大关键，大作用，大本领，断未有不先炼己而可以还丹者。 愚迷不达，欲妄行一时二候之功．鲜不蹶矣。 水火须要均平，不可偏胜。
chunks.translated_text:
In the tenth month, water and nurture—do not miss the moment.
At *zi*, advance the Yang fire, tiger and dragon unite;
at *wu*, retreat the Yin tally, naturally preserve and secure.

[Note: The central divine chamber is called the Yellow Court.
Once the elixir enters here, it is called the divine elixir entering the crucible.
*The Wuzhen Pian* says: "Send it back to the earthen crucible, firmly sealed."
From this point, tend it with watering and nurture,
practicing the fire times of the great celestial cycle.
As before, advance the Yang fire at *zi*,
retreat the Yin tally at *wu*.
When Yang fire advances, tiger and dragon unite;
when Yin tally retreats, naturally preserve and secure.
This marks the boundary between dual cultivation and solitary practice.
Without a true teacher, how could one comprehend it?]

Preserve and secure, then briefly part,
sit upright, forget words, and await the hour.
Like spokes converging at the hub, cycling without end,
three hundred and sixty—do not miss the appointed time.

[Note: In solitary preservation, dragon and tiger briefly separate.
*The Cantong Qi* says: "Within, nurture the self,
abide in stillness and emptiness."
This is the meaning of sitting upright and forgetting words.
"Await the hour" refers to *The Rootless Tree*:
"Once unloaded, it will reopen at a fixed time."
*The Cantong Qi* says: "Cycle through the twelve nodes,
when one ends, begin anew."
Like spokes converging at the hub, cycling without end,
beginning again when finished.
Three hundred and sixty is the total number of the Qian and Kun hexagrams.
Qian’s number is two hundred and sixteen;
Kun’s number is one hundred and forty-four.
At *zi*, thirty-six advances, accumulating one hundred and eighty Yang lines;
at *wu*, twenty-four retreats, totaling one hundred and twenty Yin tallies.
This is Yang lines using nine—four nines make thirty-six;
Yin lines using six—four sixes make twenty-four.
Excluding *mao* and *you* for bathing, these are the numbers of the celestial cycle,
the measured limits of wondrous practice—one must not be ignorant of them.]

Do not miss the appointed time, for it sets the rule.
To awaken to the true principle, one must accord with it.
If you cling to the movement of lines and images,
you may only exhaust the spirit and wear the body thin.

[Note: Do not miss the appointed time—set the fixed limit, unalterable.
Take it as the rule. To cultivate the wondrous Dao,
first accord with the wondrous mechanism.
This true mechanism must be matched precisely—do not cling.
If you do not thoroughly awaken to the subtle mystery,
clinging to the text and fixating on images,
counting the clepsydra, weighing the lines,
the body will wear thin and the spirit labor in vain,
all effort wasted to old age.
This is all due to failing to awaken to the supreme principle within the mystery,
falling into error and confusion,
mistaking oneself for wisdom—all to no avail in the end.
Know this: without a true teacher’s guidance, not one in ten thousand will succeed.]

The body worn thin, yet the work persists,
but the heart’s machinations may not yet be at rest.
If thoughts of longing for the true err by a hair’s breadth,
lead dissolves, mercury scatters, and the elixir will not form.

[Note: "Persists" refers to the work of advancing and retreating, of small going and great coming.
When the body is worn thin and old age renders one unfit,
if one can practice this advancing and retreating,
naturally one will grow stronger day by day, with daily results.
Those who cannot do so are unsettled in mind,
a thousand worries and ten thousand anxieties leaving not a moment’s peace.
Refining lead and cooking mercury depend entirely on a still heart and a tranquil spirit.
The slightest thought or worry is already an error.
*The Mirror for Compounding the Medicine* says: "Err by a hair’s breadth, and the elixir will not form."
*The Wuzhen Pian* says: "A hair’s difference, and the elixir will not be made." This is the meaning.]

If the elixir does not form, reflect on refining the self,
for all is lost through failing to grasp the principle within the mystery.
When water dries and fire scorches, adjust and harmonize;
when punishment and virtue arrive at the gate, know when to advance and retreat.

[Note: The elixir’s failure to form is entirely due to the self not being sufficiently refined.
The ancients said: "If the self is not sufficiently refined, dare not return the elixir."
The work of refining the self is vast indeed!
It is said: "Cultivating immortality has limits; refining the self has none."
The two words "refining the self" are the great key,
the great function, the great foundation of elixir cultivation.
There has never been one who did not first refine the self and yet could return the elixir.
The deluded and ignorant, failing to understand,
rashly attempt the work of the twelve hours—few do not stumble.
Water and fire must be balanced, not allowed to dominate.]

chunks.translated_text:
Fire blazes and turns parched, water overflows and spills—all hinges on harmonizing to the mean.
When punishment and virtue arrive at the gate, they stand at the threshold of life and death.
This is the moment of bathing; one must know when to advance and retreat, never transgressing the measure.

Knowing advance and retreat, fear no misfortune—
within the crucible, a single crimson point is refined.
A child is born, its *qi* of *dui*-metal full,
three years of nurturing leave it dull as the deaf and mute.

The Dao of the elixir first demands knowing advance and retreat, fortune and misfortune.
"Advance and retreat" refer to advancing the fire and retreating the tally.
Receiving *qi* brings fortune; error brings misfortune.
If advance and retreat are clear, never overstepping the rule, fortune comes without misfortune—
a grain of golden elixir glows crimson in the crucible.
When the ten-month gestation is complete, the infant emerges from the crown,
the *qi* of *dui*-metal fulfilled—here it must be born.
Thereafter, three years of nursing care differ little from prior nurturing.
Worldly affairs and mundane attachments are utterly cast off, as if deaf and mute.

Seeming deaf and mute, yet truly joyous—
in stillness, the spirit is tuned to leave the husk.
East, west, south, north—roam freely,
entering and exiting, riding a white crane.

People see him as dull and witless,
devoid of lively spirit—how could they know
he wears coarse cloth yet holds jade within,
concealing priceless treasure?
In the realm of nothingness, the boundless sea of extinction—
true joy, who can know it?
Who attains this may here refine the spirit to depart the shell.
Thus: by morning roaming the Northern Sea, by evening lodging in Cangwu,
gazing upon the famous mountains within the six directions,
beholding the diverse winds of the eight quarters,
riding a crane through the sky, coming and going at will—
what joy can compare?

Riding the white crane, free of dust,
the immortals of the Three Isles gather in assembly.
Though mulberry fields turn to azure seas,
my spirit remains untroubled, poised in the numinous terrace.

The preceding verse speaks of the Dao perfected and virtue accomplished, lying in wait for the appointed time;
this verse tells of the Great One’s summons, moving to dwell in the Central Continent.
Shedding the mortal dust, ascending to the immortal realm.
The Three Isles lie in the sea, where immortals gather—
their lifespan spans myriad eons.
Henceforth, though seas turn to mulberry fields,
my numinous terrace remains serene,
wandering freely in the realm of true light and dharma—boundless and endless!

Accumulating merit and virtue to transcend the mortal world,
yet still manifesting transformations to guide the deluded masses—
only then are a man’s aspirations fulfilled.

The ranks of immortals vary by the magnitude of merit.
Thus the Yellow Emperor, considering great deeds, descended to the world:
first life as a commoner, next as a minister, then as a sovereign.
Therefore, in the mortal realm, one accumulates virtue and merit—
in the celestial realm of purity, building merit is difficult;
in the turbid world of men, establishing merit is easy.
No immortal or buddha lacks compassion,
wandering the dusty world to save the suffering,
now manifesting miracles, now silently aiding,
guiding the deluded across the sea of transformation.
As it is said: only after delivering all beings does one become a buddha.
Then, with merit accomplished and name fulfilled,
the heart of a great man, the aspirations of a heroic man—
all is resolved in this moment.
What greater virtue or grander achievement could surpass this?

Dao, Dao, Dao—no artifice, no subtlety;
Mystery, mystery, mystery—no need for many words.
Unlocking the gates, unfolding the apertures is not hard.

[Note: The word *Dao* is itself but a forced name.

It is the stem of the formless, the root of the Supreme Ultimate.
No single thing *is* the Dao, yet no single thing *is not* the Dao.
Most utterly ordinary, utterly without artifice or subtlety.
The word *mystery* speaks of a principle profound yet subtle,
yet the matter itself is utterly simple.
Fifty hundred words cannot exhaust it; half a phrase suffices.
Ancestor Yuchan said: "Half a word, a single phrase, and mystery is penetrated—
what need for alchemical texts in the tens of thousands?"
He also said: "The oral instructions contain few words,
all held within half a phrase."
Though the work of unlocking the gates and unfolding the apertures exists,
it is, in truth, easy.
Only let the heart be steadfast, and nothing is difficult.
The *gates* are the Three Passes; the *apertures* are the Mysterious Aperture.
As the alchemical classics say: "When the Mysterious Aperture opens, all apertures open;
the Three Passes are penetrated without labor."]

Discern the female and male, keep both swords whole,
lay the foundation, refine the self, and gather the postnatal.
Though the postnatal is called impure substance,
first ingest the postnatal, then the prenatal.

[Note: The two swords, female and male, have been with us since birth,
worn upon the body—not bestowed by any master.
Few comprehend this principle, and fewer still can wield them.
Wield them to lay the foundation, and the foundation is laid;
wield them to return the elixir, and the work is accomplished.
*Laying the foundation* means gathering the prenatal within the postnatal—
the art of extending life and prolonging the years.
*Returning the elixir* means gathering the prenatal within the prenatal—
the task of becoming a buddha or attaining immortality.
The prenatal arises from the formless; the postnatal emerges from impure substance.
The prenatal is without form; the postnatal has substance.
Both are but a single *qi*, yet differ in their prenatal and postnatal nature.
*The Mirror of Ingesting the Medicine* says: "Prenatal *qi*, postnatal *qi*—
he who obtains them is ever as though drunk."]

This wondrous instruction must be transmitted by a master;
without a true teacher, all effort is in vain.

chunks.original_text: 筑基工夫往前进，火候屯蒙要抽添。 【注：欲学此道，先要洞明真诀。 此诀非师不传，愚迷或得一知半解，便想行工，岂知玄理幽深，非得真师，逐节开陈，寸步指点，亦是枉然。 初关进步筑基，便要勇猛直前。 有进无退，即是真功。 火候进退，按爻而行。 朝屯暮蒙，日各两卦。 有抽有添，抽铅添汞，皆有一定之则。 《灵宝毕法》曰：可抽之时不可添。 】 要抽添，认真铅，十三四五六相连。 审黄道，知端的，亦要看经五千言。 【注：抽添之诀，先要认定真铅，不得错误。 十三四五六者，选鼎之则也。 鼎有大小，有强弱，有迟早，不可一概，用之有一定之期。 相连者，连类而及，其妙限在于审黄道、知端的也。 黄道者，日月所行之道； 端的者，如矢之端正中的，不差绳墨，不违矩度也。 其要妙在于看经。 自不能看，探候者看而说之。
chunks.translated_text:
Advancing the work of *laying the foundation*,
the firing times of *zhun* and *meng* require withdrawal and addition.
**[Note: To study this Dao, one must first thoroughly understand the true instructions.
These instructions are not transmitted without a master. Should the foolish and deluded gain but a partial or superficial grasp, they may attempt to practice—yet how could they fathom the profound and subtle principles? Without a true teacher to unfold each step and guide every inch, all effort remains in vain.
At the initial barrier, advancing to lay the foundation demands bold and relentless progress—no retreat, only true achievement. The firing times advance and withdraw according to the hexagrams. *Zhun* at dawn, *meng* at dusk, each day encompassing two hexagrams. There is withdrawal and addition: withdrawing lead, adding mercury, all governed by fixed principles. *The Perfect Methods of the Numinous Treasure* states: "When it is time to withdraw, do not add."]**

To withdraw and add, recognize true lead—
thirteen, fourteen, fifteen, sixteen, linked in sequence.
Examine the Yellow Path, know the precise target,
and also study the *Five Thousand Words*.
**[Note: The instructions for withdrawal and addition first require identifying true lead without error.
"Thirteen, fourteen, fifteen, sixteen" refers to the principles for selecting the crucible. Crucibles vary in size, strength, speed, and timing; they cannot be treated uniformly, for their use follows a fixed schedule. "Linked in sequence" means extending by category, its subtlety lying in examining the Yellow Path and knowing the precise target.
The Yellow Path is the course traversed by the sun and moon; the precise target is like an arrow striking dead center, neither deviating from the plumb line nor transgressing the square. Its essential subtlety lies in studying the scriptures. If one cannot study them alone, the observer must study and then explain.]**

chunks.original_text: 《阴符》三百字，《道德》五千言，无非说此经之妙。 二七为佳。 五千四十八而合当。 知此便是知道，行此便可飞升。 】 药苗新，用心看，铅光发现三日前。 癸水将至须急采，差之毫发不成丹。 【注：山头月白。 药苗新嫩，此是先天兆形，正好用心看经。 真铅将到，三日之前，其精光早耀于西南庚位，现出蛾眉一痕。 《契》曰：潜潭见象，发现精光，此时癸水将到，当急用采工，勿致差殊。 毫发一谬，丹即难成。 《入药镜》曰：差毫发，不成丹。 】 未采药，立匡廓，交合之时用橐龠。 用橐龠，近我身，不看天体枉为作。 【注：大药将产，堪下采工。 先于未采之前，立定匡廓。 匡廓者，即橐龠之匡廓也。 交合坎离，须用橐龠。 此采药之器，谓之太极把柄，入室施工之要具也。 《入药镜》曰：上鹊桥，下鹊桥，天应星，地应潮。 用之之法，远不离人，近就我身，亦如乾坤天地，坎离日月，体配阴阳，运行水火。 不解法天效地，便是枉为妄作，缘木求鱼，空劳神矣。 】
chunks.translated_text:
The *Three Hundred Characters of the Yin Talisman* and the *Five Thousand Words of the Dao and Its Virtue* speak of nothing but the wonders of this sutra. Two sevens make the finest. Five thousand and forty-eight align perfectly. To know this is to know the Dao; to practice this is to ascend in flight.

When the medicinal sprout is fresh, observe with care—three days before the lead’s radiance appears. As the *gui*-water approaches, swiftly gather it; a hair’s breadth of error, and the elixir will not form.

**[Annotation: The moon whitens the mountain peak. The medicinal sprout is tender and new, this being the sign of the primordial omen—just the time to observe the sutras with care. As true lead nears, three days prior, its essence-light shines early in the southwest *geng* position, revealing a crescent’s trace. As the *Canticle* says: "In the hidden depths, an image appears; the essence-light manifests." At this moment, as *gui*-water approaches, one must urgently apply the work of gathering, lest the slightest deviation occur. A hair’s error, and the elixir will not form. The *Mirror of Entering the Medicine* states: "A hair’s breadth off, the elixir will not form."]**

Before gathering the medicine, establish the framework. At the time of union, employ the bellows. Use the bellows, drawing it near to your body—heed not the celestial bodies, or your efforts are in vain.

**[Annotation: As the great medicine is about to emerge, the work of gathering may begin. First, before gathering, establish the framework. The framework is that of the bellows. In the union of *kan* and *li*, the bellows must be used. This instrument for gathering medicine is called the handle of the Great Ultimate, the essential tool for entering the chamber and applying the work. The *Mirror of Entering the Medicine* says: "Above, the magpie bridge; below, the magpie bridge. Heaven responds to the stars, earth to the tides." The method of its use is neither far from the person nor distant from the self—just as *qian* and *kun* are heaven and earth, *kan* and *li* are the sun and moon, their bodies paired as yin and yang, their movements circulating water and fire. Failing to model oneself on heaven and earth is to labor in vain, climbing a tree to seek fish, exhausting the spirit to no purpose.]**

chunks.original_text: 知癸生，晓癸现，三十时辰两日半。 采取只在一时辰，六候只于二候见。 【注：果能知癸生之的时，晓癸现之方位，只在两日半之间，三十时辰之内，真正天机，实隐于此。 所谓“采有时，取有日”是也。 然此采取，不多时候，只在一时。 《悟真篇》曰：一时辰内管丹成，即此一时。 分为六候，前二候得药，只此二候，便见工夫。 】 外四候，别有干。 得药之时勿贪乱。 如痴如醉更省言，牢关牢锁牢上圈。 【注：一时分为六候。 前二候既已得药归炉，尚余四候，另有炉鼎，另有事干。 盖前二候，系采药真工； 后四候，乃烹炼至诀。 丹经曰：“二候采牟尼，四候别神工”是也。 但得药之时，切要正心诚意，戒慎恐惧，不可稍起贪爱之心，致乱邦国。 《契》曰：邪道险阻，倾危国家。 此时如醉如痴，更要节省言语，丹入黄庭，牢关牢锁。 《契》曰：守御固密，遏绝奸邪，曲阁相连，以戒不虞，慎之至也。 】 择定饮食莫太过，又恐伤舟又霍乱。 减酸咸，常咬淡，黄婆伏侍用心看。 【注：未饥先食，未饱先止，此养生家之诀。 《天仙正理》亦谓调养口腹，安静气体，易易事耳。 择定饮食者，戒荤腥，绝滋味，减酸咸。 只用精洁芽茶淡饭。 丹乃色身至宝，难得而易失。 刻刻爱护，不可伤之，致霍乱不宁。 黄婆伏侍，切要殷勤，细心探看，不可怠惰，致令失时，最宜叮嘱。 】 一时饥饱失前功，铅散汞枯两不恋。 十月工夫要勤咽，勤咽之时防危险。 【注：一息不谨，则铅散汞枯，阴阳不调，龙虎易位，两不相恋。 此皆饥饱不节之故。 中关十月大周天功夫，刻不可间断，须要勤咽勤炼，寸步防危。 钟离祖曰：一年沐浴防危险，十月调和须谨节。 】 颇得道理明性歌，得之莫作容易看。

Know when *gui* is born, understand when *gui* appears—thirty *shichen* span two and a half days. Gathering occurs in but a single *shichen*, the six *hou* manifest in only two. [Note: If one truly knows the precise moment when *gui* is born and the direction from which it emerges, within these two and a half days and thirty *shichen*, the true celestial mechanism lies concealed here. This is what is meant by "gathering has its time, harvesting has its day." Yet this gathering takes but a brief moment, confined to a single *shichen*. *The Awakening to Reality* says: "Within one *shichen* the elixir is complete"—this is that very moment. Divided into six *hou*, the medicine is obtained in the first two; only in these two does the work become evident.]

The remaining four *hou* serve other purposes. When the medicine is obtained, do not covet or disorder. Be as one drunk or dazed, speak sparingly, fasten the gates and locks, secure the enclosure. [Note: One *shichen* is divided into six *hou*. Once the medicine is obtained in the first two and returned to the furnace, the remaining four *hou* involve another crucible and other tasks. The first two *hou* constitute the true work of gathering the medicine; the latter four are the supreme secrets of refinement. As the alchemical classics say: "Two *hou* gather the *mauni*, four *hou* employ divine skill." Yet when the medicine is obtained, one must rectify the mind and sincerely intend, being cautious and reverent, without the slightest stirring of covetous desire, lest the state be thrown into chaos. *The Canticle* says: "The heterodox path is perilous and treacherous, toppling nations and endangering the realm." At this time, be as one drunk or dazed, speak even less, and once the elixir enters the Yellow Court, fasten the gates and locks securely. *The Canticle* says: "Guard and defend with firm resolve, block and sever all perverse influences. The winding chambers connect, to ward against the unforeseen—this is the utmost caution."]

Choose your diet carefully, neither too much nor too little, lest you harm the vessel or invite disorder. Reduce sour and salty flavors, partake only of the bland. The Yellow Dame attends with watchful care. [Note: Eat before hunger arises, stop before fullness—this is the secret of the masters of longevity. *The True Principles of Celestial Immortality* also teaches that regulating diet and calming the body are simple matters. "Choosing your diet carefully" means abstaining from meat and strong flavors, reducing sour and salty tastes, consuming only pure, sprouted teas and plain rice. The elixir is the supreme treasure of the physical form, difficult to obtain and easy to lose. Cherish it at every moment, lest harm befall it and disorder arise. The Yellow Dame’s attendance must be diligent and attentive; she must observe with care, never slackening, lest the moment be missed—this bears the strictest admonition.]

A single lapse in hunger or satiety undoes all prior work: lead scatters, mercury withers, and the two no longer embrace. The ten-month work demands diligent swallowing; when swallowing diligently, guard against danger. [Note: A single careless breath scatters the lead and withers the mercury, disrupting the harmony of yin and yang, transposing dragon and tiger, so they no longer embrace. This all stems from immoderate hunger or satiety. The great celestial cycle of the middle barrier’s ten-month work must never be interrupted; one must swallow and refine diligently, vigilant at every step. Ancestor Zhongli said: "In the year’s bathing, guard against danger; in the ten months’ regulation, exercise utmost caution."]

Once you grasp the principle and comprehend the *Song of Illuminating Nature*, do not regard it as something easily attained.
